source.p: The transport and reporting mechanism (TERM) was set up on request of the EU transport ministers in 1998. The main aim of TERM is to monitor the progress and effectiveness of transport and environment integration strategies on the basis of a core set of indicators.
In addition to TERM, the EEA also addresses other specific transport and environment issues:

ul.li: Transport subsidies: EEA assessed the extent of subsidies in the transport sector and how they affect the balance between transport modes

Transport emission inventories: EEA is undertaking studies aiming to improve the estimation of transport emissions both with regard to accuracy and geographical distribution. This includes work on standardised emission factors for use in the creation of national inventories (COPERT model, work undertaken by ETC/ACC http://air-climate.eionet.europa.eu/) and work on the geographical distribution of emissions in order to better estimate the health benefits of policies aimed at, for example, reducing emissions in urban areas
Air quality work, dealing with transport's contribution to air quality problems (http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/air)
Transport's contribution to climate change, and mitigation strategies such as emission trading systems (http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/climate)
Transport noise monitoring (http://www.eea.europa.eu/themes/noise)

source.p: Households, and the consumption patterns of the people within them, affect the environment in a myriad of ways, the most important being:

ul.li: energy consumption, one of the major drivers of greenhouse gas emissions and therefore climate change;
water consumption and pollution;
land use, with the construction of new towns and increasingly far-flung transport networks;
the production of a wide variety of waste and through sewage treatment systems;
the production of other pollutants, such as chemicals harmful to the ozone layer, gases which contribute to acid rain and other substances harmful to human health.

source.p: Unlike other sectors, these problems could be reduced through changing consumers habits and lifestyles, rather than introducing advanced and expensive new technologies. Unfortunately, consumption patterns have headed in the opposite direction  while Europeans may use more energy efficient appliances in their homes, for example, as a whole, their homes consume more energy than they did before.

Probably the most important trend can be found in Europes demographics. While Europes population is growing slowly, the number of households is growing much faster. Even if the environmental impact of each household was reduced, therefore, the sectors overall impact could remain at todays levels.

source.p: The development of European agriculture over the 1990s presents a mixed picture as far as the environment is concerned. On the one hand, the trend towards more intensive and industrialised agriculture has continued, driving large-scale use of fertilisers, herbicides, insecticides, and fungicides, and the continued pollution of Europes waters.

As a result, some of the sectors most pressing environmental problems remain as serious now as they were a decade ago. Moreover, the increasing competition in the sector has seen some farmland abandoned and jobs lost in marginal areas  farmland now accounts for 44% of the EUs land area, down from 49% in 1980.

On the other hand, the 1990s saw a number of new trends develop, driven probably in part by public unease which was strengthened by the arrival of BSE, or mad cow disease. The amount of land devoted to organic agriculture, for example, is growing rapidly and is expected to reach 5-10% of the EUs farmland by 2005. The agri-environment measures within the EUs Common Agricultural Policy have also been adopted more quickly than predicted.

These positive trends, however, are only a beginning: while the share of the CAPs budget which is tied to environmental improvement doubled during the 1990s, for example, it is still only 10%. The overall view is of an industry which is becoming increasingly divided between marginal areas, supported by a variety of regulations and subsidies, and areas of highly intensive and unsustainable agriculture.

source.p: The air we breathe should be clean. From a human health perspective, the main outstanding air pollution problems are tropospheric ozone and particulate matter. Acidification and ozone remain the main threats to ecosystems.
A relatively small number of pollutants (SO x , NO x , NH x , NMVOC) and fine particulates are the main causes of these problems.
A significant development during the past few years has been a shift to a multi-pollutant, multi-effect air pollution abatement strategy.

Such a policy which recognises that reducing a limited number of pollutants can have a positive effect on various air pollution problems. This approach has led to international legal instruments that impose nationally-differentiated targets for emission reductions of four main pollutants. As a sub-stantial part of the emissions result from the burning of fossil fuels, an effective measure is to reduce the use of fossil energy sources. The measures that will be required to reach the Kyoto Protocol targets for greenhouse gas emissions will therefore also result in reductions in air pollution.

trans-unit.source: Vast amounts of waste and pollution end up in the seas. During the past years, public concern has led to a range of national, regional, European and international initiatives to reduce the flow of toxic chemicals into the sea and back, via the marine food chain, onto our plates. The indicators show that these measures can turn the tide, reducing the flow into the sea of all six hazardous substances examined. The impact on living marine organisms, however, is not as clear. Moreover, there remain around another 10,000 chemicals flowing into the marine environment for which no or insufficient measures have been taken.

trans-unit.source:
Permanent grasslands are important for biodiversity and also play a major, though not always well-recognised or understood, environmental and social role.
 
Permanent grasslands are found all over Europe, and as the EU's enlargement programme (especially into Eastern Europe) continues, the total amount of permanent grasslands will increase. However, the overall extent of permanent grasslands in Europe has been falling gradually for several decades due to many factors: afforestation, intensive farming methods, development of sites for housing, etc.
How grassland areas evolve will depend on the implementation of a number of legal and financial instruments - which may well have conflicting objectives - and local, property-related factors may result in neighbouring farmers taking completely different decisions affecting the grasslands within their properties.
The prospects for grasslands in the short and long term may, however, change quite dramatically, for example by the outbreak of diseases such as BSE and Foot-and-Mouth and/or more rapid adoption of organic farming methods, leading to less intensive use of land. The same pressures could instead result in more afforestation or intensive crop-farming, as dairy production declines.
Pressures on grassland habitats are steadily increasing: 60% of the newly-afforested areas in the EU were previously permanent pastures of grassland; 37% was arable land, and only 3% was permanent cropland.

source.p: Emissions of dangerous substances from local sources may produce far-reaching effects on the quality of soil and water, particularly groundwater, with important impacts on human and ecosystems health.

A number of economic activities causing soil pollution can be clearly identified across Europe. These relate, in particular, to losses during industrial operations and waste disposal from municipal and industrial sources. Management of contaminated sites aims at assessing the impacts of contamination caused by local sources and at taking measures to satisfy environmental standards according to existing legal requirements.

These indicators track the progress in the management of contaminated sites in Europe and the related expenditures from the public and private sectors. They also show the contribution of main economic activities responsible for soil contamination and the major pollutants involved.

source.p: Tourism will soon be Europes largest service industry. Europe is already the worlds favourite destination, with the sector generating up to 12% of GDP, 6% of employment, and 30% of external trade. Tourism demand is forecast to grow by almost 50% by 2010, adding some 2-3 million more jobs to the nine million it currently supports.

Any industry already that large and growing that fast is going to cause environmental problems, and tourism is no exception. The industry is not just getting bigger - the way people are going on holiday is changing. The growing trend is for people to take more and shorter trips and to travel further from home. As a result, the industrys transport-related environmental problems, already significant, are expected to grow even faster than tourism itself.

When on holiday, moreover, people tend to consume more energy and water and produce more waste. More and more Europeans are also building second homes, which have low occupancy rates and take up far more land than other accommodation types.

Finally, most of these pressures are concentrated in a few small regions during a few weeks of the year, making dealing with these problems even more difficult. The Mediterranean coast, for example, is expected to see around 300 million tourists in 2025, up from 135 million in 1990.

source.p: The cornerstones of the EUs strategy to coping with waste are to:

ul.li: prevent waste in the first place;
recycle waste;
turn waste into a greenhouse neutral energy source;
optimise the final disposal of waste, including its transport.

source.p: Although the EU has a number of targets and Directives supporting these aims, the data is patchy due to a lack of consistency across the EU. What is abundantly clear, however, is that some of these targets are not being met.

To begin with, a wide range of different waste streams are increasing in volume, from consumers generating too much households waste to more wastewater treatment plants producing larger amounts of sewage sludge. What is more, waste disposal methods are not coping with the increased loads, with several countries increasing the amount of biodegradeable waste sent to landfill.
Finally - and most importantly - waste generation is still linked to economic activity, meaning that, as Europes economy grows, the waste problem will grow with it.

source.p: The air we breathe should be clean. From a human health perspective, the main outstanding air pollution problems are tropospheric ozone and particulate matter. Acidification and ozone remain the main threats to ecosystems.

A relatively small number of pollutants (SOx, NOx, NH3, NMVOC) and fine particulates are the main causes of these problems. A significant development during the past few years has been a shift to a multi-pollutant, multi-effect air pollution abatement strategy.

Such a policy which recognises that reducing a limited number of pollutants can have a positive effect on various air pollution problems. This approach has led to international legal instruments that impose nationally-differentiated targets for emission reductions of four main pollutants.

As a substantial part of the emissions result from the burning of fossil fuels, an effective measure is to reduce the use of fossil energy sources. The measures that will be required to reach the Kyoto Protocol targets for greenhouse gas emissions will therefore also result in reductions in air pollution.

p.b: Major environmental challenges remain. The unsustainable development of some key economic sectors is still the major barrier to further improvements.

ul.li: We face increasing urbanisation and land abandonment.
Climate change is already here.
Progress on energy demand management is slow.
We are healthier, but exposure to pollutants remains.
We are depleting our natural resources.
We are losing biodiversity at an alarming rate.
We are increasingly exporting our environmental impacts to other continents.

source.p: Technology still has a vast potential to reduce environmental impacts. European policy-makers are however coming to realise that widespread behavioural changes are required in order to move towards a sustainable society.

If we want to seriously address Europe’s sustainability, we need a long view, far beyond two or three legislative cycles. Climate change, globalisation and demographic change are just a few factors that will profoundly change the context of policy-making in the future.
We need to take the possibility of different outcomes into account when making strategic decisions.

trans-unit.source: Biodiversity embraces the variety of genes, species and ecosystems that constitute life on Earth. We are currently witnessing a steady loss of biodiversity, with profound consequences for the natural world and for human wellbeing. The main causes are changes in natural habitats. These are due to intensive agricultural production systems, construction, quarrying, overexploitation of forests, oceans, rivers, lakes and soils, alien species invasions, pollution and — increasingly — global climate change. Europe has set a target for halting the loss of biodiversity by 2010. Recent EEA assessments show that without significant additional policy efforts, it is unlikely that the target will be reached.

Europe has set a target for halting the loss of biodiversity by 2010. Recent EEA assessments show that without significant additional policy efforts, it is unlikely that the target will be reached.

source.p: Humankind is itself a part of biodiversity, and our existence would be impossible without it. Quality of life, economic competitiveness, employment and security all rely on this natural capital. Biodiversity is crucial to 'ecosystem services', i.e. the services that nature supplies: climate regulation, water and air, soil fertility, and the production of food, fuel, fibre and medicines. It is essential for maintaining the long-term viability of agriculture and fisheries, and is the basis of many industrial processes and the production of new medicines.

In Europe, human activity has shaped biodiversity ever since the spread of agriculture and animal husbandry over 5 000 years ago. The agricultural and industrial revolutions led to dramatic and accelerating changes in land use, intensification of agriculture, urbanisation and land abandonment. This in turn has resulted in the collapse of many practices (e.g. traditional agricultural methods) that helped to maintain biodiversity-rich landscapes.

Europe's high per capita consumption and waste production means that our impact on ecosystems extends well beyond our continent. European lifestyles rely heavily on the import of resources and goods from all over the world, often encouraging unsustainable exploitation of natural resources. This leads to loss of biodiversity which in turn damages the natural capital resources on which social and economic development is based.

blockquote.p: There can be no purpose more enspiriting than to begin the age of restoration, reweaving the wondrous diversity of life that still surrounds us.
Edward O. Wilson, 'The Diversity of Life', 1992

source.p: Biodiversity loss is inextricably linked to the degradation of ecosystem services that support life on earth. The 2005 Millennium Ecosystem Assessment assessed 24 ecosystem services globally, and found that 15 of those have been degraded, affecting fisheries, timber production, water supply, waste treatment and detoxification, water purification, natural hazard protection and regulation of air quality. The EEA’s 2005 State and outlook report and its fourth pan-European assessment show that the EU is making no apparent progress towards this 2010 target of halting biodiversity loss.

p.strong: Over the past decades, environmental information has evolved from substance-by-substance monitoring to much more integrated information-gathering systems. Nevertheless, a lot more can be achieved with environmental information and communication technologies. Future studies and better information are needed to help make our policies robust over the long term.

source.h2: A long-term view requires a broad mind
source.p: Forward-looking studies have been developed for agriculture, transport and energy, climate change and air pollution. But we need more integrated, long-term assessments to effectively support strategic decision-making. We also need to broaden our impact assessments procedures.

The PRELUDE project (Prospective Environmental analysis of Land Use Development in Europe) demonstrates how we can broaden our thinking. It explores what our society and environment might look like in 2035.
source.h2: Better and more detailed environmental information
source.p: Environmental information is currently collected by a variety of organisations using techniques from satellite observation to mobile monitoring stations on our roads, to volunteers knee-deep in mud collecting water samples for laboratory analysis.

The European Environment Agency and its network intend to employ the Internet in innovative ways to gather all information and make it easily accessible to decision-makers and individual citizens alike. Our Shared Environmental Information System (SEIS) will work in all settings (local, national, regional, European and international). Ozone web and the Water Information System for Europe are the first steps to move this vision from concept to reality.

trans-unit.source: Europe's leaders have agreed to a target of halting the loss of biodiversity in Europe by 2010. A range of policies at national, EU and pan-European level are contributing to this goal. Many policies focus on specific protection measures for key species and habitats. To manage biodiversity sustainably, it is however of paramount importance to integrate biodiversity needs into the development and implementation of sectoral policies. The European Community Biodiversity Strategy aims to do this.
trans-unit.target: Europe's leaders have agreed to a target of halting the loss of biodiversity in Europe by 2010. A range of policies at national, EU and pan-European level are contributing to this goal. Many policies focus on specific protection measures for key species and habitats. To manage biodiversity sustainably, it is however of paramount importance to integrate biodiversity needs into the development and implementation of sectoral policies. The European Community Biodiversity Strategy aims to do this.

source.p: In its 2001 Strategy for Sustainable Development, the EU set itself the target to halt the loss of biodiversity and restore habitats and natural systems by 2010. The European Commission's 2006 Biodiversity Communication provides the main policy framework. It adds much-needed momentum to the 2010 target, articulates the responsibilities of EU institutions and Member States and sets out an ambitious policy approach and Action Plan proposing concrete measures.

blockquote.p: While climate change takes up much of the media attention, in one fundamental way biodiversity loss is an even more serious threat. This is because the degradation of ecosystems often reaches a point of no return — and because extinction is forever.
Stavros Dimas, EU Commissioner for Environment, Green Week 2006

source.p: EU nature conservation policy is based on two main pieces of legislation:

li.div: the Birds Directive and
the Habitats Directive

source.p: Both directives provide the basis for the Natura 2000 network, a network of nature reserves which extends across the Union to safeguard species and habitats of special European interest. EU nature conservation policy benefits from a specific financial instrument, the LIFE-Nature fund.

Biodiversity loss is caused mainly by sectoral activities. The 1998 European Community Biodiversity Strategy focuses specifically on the integration of biodiversity concerns into sectoral policies, including conservation of natural resources, agriculture, fisheries, regional policies and spatial planning, forests, energy and transport, tourism, development and economic co-operation.
Other policies relevant to biodiversity at EU level include:

ul.li: The EU Sixth Environmental Action Programme 'Our future, our choice', adopted in 2002, in which conservation of biodiversity is one of the four main issues to be tackled.
The 2004 'Message from Malahide', presenting 18 priority objectives for halting the loss of biodiversity, many of which relate to sectoral integration of biodiversity issues.

source.p: In 1992, the UN Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) marked the international community's commitment to addressing biodiversity loss. In response, the Pan‑European Biological and Landscape Diversity Strategy was endorsed by the countries covered by the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe. Embedded in the ministerial 'Environment for Europe' process, this strategy provides the only platform for pan-European cooperation on tackling biodiversity loss.

In 2002, the CBD and the Johannesburg Summit on Sustainable Development endorsed a 2010 global target to significantly reduce the current rate of biodiversity loss by 2010. In 2003, pan‑European environment ministers agreed to halt the loss of biodiversity by 2010 in the Kiev Resolution on Biodiversity.

The CBD establishes a national-level obligation for biodiversity planning. Countries must develop national strategies which reflect how the Convention's objectives are to be achieved, and related action plans must set out the steps to be taken towards these goals. A list of these national biodiversity strategies and action plans is available on the CBD website.

trans-unit.source: Climate change is one of our greatest environmental, social and economic threats. The warming of the climate system is unequivocal, says the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). Observations show increases in global average air and ocean temperatures, widespread melting of snow and ice, and rising global mean sea level. It is very likely that most of the warming can be attributed to the emissions of greenhouse gases by human activities.
trans-unit.target: Climate change is one of our greatest environmental, social and economic threats. The warming of the climate system is unequivocal, says the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC). Observations show increases in global average air and ocean temperatures, widespread melting of snow and ice, and rising global mean sea level. It is very likely that most of the warming can be attributed to the emissions of greenhouse gases by human activities.

blockquote.p: Climate change represents the greatest and widest-ranging market failure ever seen.

Sir Nicholas Stern, Head of the UK Government Economic Service
and former World Bank Chief Economist, 2006

source.p: Over the past 150 years, mean temperature has increased by almost 0.8 ºC globally and by about 1 ºC in Europe. Eleven of the last twelve years (1995–2006) rank among the 12 warmest years in the instrumental record of global surface temperature (since 1850). Without global action to limit emissions, the IPCC expects that global temperatures may increase further by 1.8 to 4.0 ºC by 2100. This means that temperature increase since pre-industrial times would exceed 2 °C. Beyond this threshold irreversible and possibly catastrophic changes become far more likely. (More information)

The impacts of climate change are already being observed and are projected to become more pronounced. Extreme weather events, including heat waves, droughts and floods, are expected to become more frequent and intense. In Europe the largest temperature increases are in southern Europe and the Arctic region. Precipitation decreases in southern Europe and increases in the north/north-west. This leads to impacts on natural ecosystems, human health and water resources. Economic sectors, such as forestry, agriculture, tourism and buildings will suffer mostly adverse consequences. The agricultural sector in northern Europe may benefit from a limited temperature rise.
To halt climate change, global greenhouse gas emissions must be reduced significantly, and policies are put in place to do so.
The main sources of man-made greenhouse gases are:

ul.li: burning of fossil fuels in electricity generation, transport, industry and households;
agriculture and land use changes like deforestation;
land filling of waste; and
use of industrial fluorinated gases.

source.p: Even if policies and efforts to reduce emissions are effective, some climate change is inevitable. We must therefore also develop strategies and actions to adapt to the impacts of climate change in Europe and especially beyond, since the least developed countries are among the most vulnerable, having the least financial and technical capacity to adapt.

trans-unit.source: The EEA's work on biodiversity data, indicators and assessments focuses on conservation measures (such as protected areas or species protection) and on the integration of biodiversity concerns into sectors such as forestry, agriculture and fisheries. Key activities also include the 'Streamlining European 2010 Biodiversity Indicators' process and the management of the European Community Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism (link). The EEA is set to become the designated European data centre for biodiversity.
trans-unit.target: The EEA's work on biodiversity data, indicators and assessments focuses on conservation measures (such as protected areas or species protection) and on the integration of biodiversity concerns into sectors such as forestry, agriculture and fisheries. Key activities also include the 'Streamlining European 2010 Biodiversity Indicators' process and the management of the European Community Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism (link). The EEA is set to become the designated European data centre for biodiversity.

blockquote.p: Look deep, deep into nature, and then you will understand everything better.
Albert Einstein

source.p: The EEA will over the next years become the European Data Centre for Biodiversity, storing and maintaining EEA data sets, linking to complementary data sets owned by others, developing biodiversity indicator sets, and providing access to European biodiversity data more generally.

The 'Streamlining European 2010 Biodiversity Indicators' ( SEBI 2010) project aims to help monitor progress towards the 2010 target. SEBI 2010 streamlines national, regional and global-level indicators, and ensures that the data flows for the production of indicators are in place.
The EEA also regularly updates key biodiversity indicators under its core set of indicators.
The EUNIS database provides public access to species, habitat types and sites in Europe.

With quality data flows in place, increasing emphasis will be put on making integrated assessments of how well biodiversity policies are working, how other policies impact on biodiversity, and what policy changes may be needed. Recent assessments can be found in the EEA State and outlook 2005 report and its fourth pan-European assessment.
Major upcoming assessments are:

li.div: An assessment of progress towards the European 2010 biodiversity target, based on a set of specific biodiversity indicators, scheduled for 2008.
An ecosystem assessment for Europe, to be concluded in 2012.

source.p: Specific projects from the EEA management plan cover assessments of the:

li.div: Natura 2000 network;
farmland and rural areas;
high nature value farmland;
forest ecosystems, and
economic evaluation of benefits from nature management.

source.p: In support to the Convention on Biological Diversity, the EEA also manages the European Community Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism (CHM). The CHM promotes technical cooperation and technology transfer within the European Union and its Member States, within the pan-European Region and the rest of the world.

The EEA’s Biodiversity and ecosystems group leads the Agency's work in this field. The group works closely with the European Topic Centre on Biodiversity (ETC/BD) and with EEA's country network (Eionet).

trans-unit.source: The threat of climate change is being addressed globally by the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Its Kyoto Protocol sets binding emission targets for those developed countries that have ratified it, such as the EU Member States. This is only a first step towards the more substantial global emission reductions that will be needed.
trans-unit.target: The threat of climate change is being addressed globally by the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC). Its Kyoto Protocol sets binding emission targets for those developed countries that have ratified it, such as the EU Member States. This is only a first step towards the more substantial global emission reductions that will be needed.

blockquote.p: The challenge of climate change, and what we do about it, will define us, our era, and ultimately, our global legacy.
UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon, 2007

source.p: The UNFCCC long-term objective is 'to stabilise atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system'. The Kyoto Protocol is a first step to achieve this. It sets emission reduction targets for many industrialised countries, including most EU Member States, and limits the emission increases of the remaining countries:

ul.li: The 15 older EU Member States have a joint emission reduction target of 8 % below 1990 levels by 2008–2012 below 1990 levels (video). Through an internal EU agreement some EU Member States are allowed increases in emissions, while others should decrease emissions.
Most new Member States have targets of – 6 to – 8 % from their base years (mostly 1990).

source.p: The United States of America, which have high greenhouse gas emissions, have not ratified the Protocol.

Countries are expected to meet their target mainly through domestic policies and measures. They are allowed to meet part of their emission reduction targets by investing in emission reducing projects in developing countries (Clean Developing Mechanism, CDM) or in developed ones (Joint Implementation). The CDM is also meant to support sustainable development, e.g. by financing renewable energy projects.

The IPCC calls for global emission reductions of about 50 % by the middle of the 21st century. This implies 60–80 % reduction of emissions by developed countries. Developing countries with large emissions, such as China, India and Brazil, will have to limit their emission growth.
A post-2012 international agreement is being negotiated within the UNFCCC. The aim is to reach an agreement at the climate conference planned in Copenhagen for December 2009.

Many European countries have adopted national programmes aimed at reducing emissions. Various policies and measures have also been adopted at the EU level through the European Climate Change Programme, for example:

ul.li: increased use of renewable energy (wind, solar, biomass) and combined heat and power installations;
improvements in energy efficiency in e.g. buildings, industry, household appliances;
reduction of carbon dioxide emissions from new passenger cars;
abatement measures in manufacturing industry;
measures to reduce emissions from landfills.

source.p: The EU's carbon dioxide Emission Trading Scheme (video) is the cornerstone of EU efforts to reduce emissions cost-effectively. In March 2007, the EU leaders endorsed an ambitious climate change and energy plan to limit EU greenhouse gas emissions by at least 20 % by 2020 (from 1990 levels) and achieve, by 2020, a target of 20 % of total EU primary energy use through renewable energy. In January 2008, the European Commission proposed a new energy and climate package to achieve emission reduction target (video). Various sectors like agriculture, transport and construction and all Member States will have to play their role and contribute to Europe's targets according to their respective financial capacities. For energy-intensive sectors, such as steel and chemicals, the Commission proposes to strengthen the EU's Emissions Trading System to help reach the 20% objective. Reducing greenhouse gas emissions will require an increased use of renewable energies, which also implies a more diversified energy supply for Europe.
New policy areas for which additional emission reductions measures are being developed include aviation (video), CO2 and cars  (video), and carbon capture and storage (video) .

Some EEA member countries have prepared National Climate Change Adaptation Strategies or have started preparing these. The European Commission’s 2007 Green Paper on 'Adapting to climate change in Europe — options for EU action' is currently under stakeholder consultation.

target.p: The UNFCCC long-term objective is 'to stabilise atmospheric greenhouse gas concentrations at a level that would prevent dangerous anthropogenic interference with the climate system'. The Kyoto Protocol is a first step to achieve this. It sets emission reduction targets for many industrialised countries, including most EU Member States, and limits the emission increases of the remaining countries:

ul.li: The 15 older EU Member States have a joint emission reduction target of 8 % below 1990 levels by 2008–2012 below 1990 levels (video). Through an internal EU agreement some EU Member States are allowed increases in emissions, while others should decrease emissions.
Most new Member States have targets of – 6 to – 8 % from their base years (mostly 1990).

trans-unit.source: Problems like climate change, biodiversity loss and natural resource use have long-term implications which require long-term policy solutions. To make informed strategic decisions, we must try to anticipate what lies ahead and grasp ongoing, emerging and latent developments. If we want to seriously address Europe's sustainability, we have to look beyond two legislative cycles and more. However, a long view requires a broad mind: the key challenges facing Europe can change significantly with time. Environmental scenarios, outlooks and other types of forward studies help us to address discontinuity and uncertainties of future developments and to design robust policies that can withstand the test of time.

source.p: Forward-looking studies, such as scenarios and outlooks, have been widely conducted in international organisations, governments, companies and non-governmental organisations over the last few decades.

The long-term emission scenarios of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) are well-known. They have been widely used for the analysis of climate change, its impacts and mitigation options, and to support international negotiations on setting long-term targets.

Another prominent example is the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment, which developed scenarios to analyse outcomes for global ecosystem services in different future situations. The United Nations Environment Programme (UNEP) uses its Global Environment Outlook scenarios to frame its long-term analyses. Major international organisations such as the World Bank, the International Energy Agency and the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) also frequently publish long-term projections and analyses.

There is no standard recipe for analysing the future. It can be done in a purely quantitative fashion, taking data and (mathematical) models to project future trends and analyse their uncertainties (also called outlook analysis); it can combine quantitative analysis with qualitative analysis in the form of narratives, diagrams and images; or it can rely on a qualitative analysis only.

Thinking about the future requires thinking in alternatives. The future is full of uncertainty, and lots of things can happen. Scenarios are powerful tools in this regard as they help to think 'out of the box'. Scenarios are neither predictions nor forecasts. They are plausible descriptions of how the future may unfold for our organisations, our issues, our nations and even our world, based on 'if-then' propositions. A typical environmental scenario includes a representation of the initial situation and a storyline that describes the key driving forces and the changes that provide an image of the future.

For example, the EEA's PRELUDE scenarios help us to rethink our current approaches towards biodiversity and landscape protection. They highlight a number of factors that could jeopardise their effectiveness and efficiency in the mid- to long-term, such as demographic changes and climate change.

trans-unit.source: Energy gives personal comfort and mobility to people, and is essential for the generation of industrial, commercial and societal wealth. On the other hand, energy production and consumption place considerable pressures on the environment (including heat and electricity production, oil refining and its final use in households, services, industry and transport). These pressures include the emission of greenhouse gases and air pollutants, land-use, waste generation and oil spills. They contribute to climate change, damage natural ecosystems and the man-made environment, and cause adverse effects to human health.

trans-unit.source: With its information on climate change, the EEA supports the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol in the EU, the evaluation of EU policies and the development of long-term strategies to mitigate and adapt to climate change. EEA's information (data, indicators, assessments, projections) focuses on greenhouse gas emission trends, policies and measures, and on climate change impacts and adaptation actions in Europe. The EEA will become the European data centre on greenhouse gas emissions and climate change impacts.

The EEA will become the European data centre on greenhouse gas emissions and climate change impacts.

source.p: The EEA's climate change and energy group leads the Agency's work in this field. The group works closely with the European Topic Centre on Air and Climate Change (ETC/ACC) and with EEA's country network (Eionet).
source.h2: Greenhouse gas monitoring, accounting and reporting
source.p: EEA's work on greenhouse gas emissions aims to support the implementation of the Kyoto Protocol in the EU. Key activities and products include:

ul.li: an annual European Community greenhouse gas inventory; data and reports can be viewed on EEA's greenhouse gas data viewer. The 'Frequently asked questions' and the 2008 report give more information;
support to the IPCC and the UNFCCC on methodological issues and reviews related to GHG inventories;

an annual indicator report on greenhouse gas emission trends and projections, tracking progress of the European Community, its Member States and other EEA member countries, towards their Kyoto targets. This also evaluates the effectiveness of national and EU policies in achieving these targets, with a focus on energy and transport;
a regular evaluation of the implementation, by the Member States, of the Emissions Trading Directive;
regular updates of indicators on greenhouse gas emissions trends and projections as part of the EEA core set of indicators.

source.p: The EEA's work on climate change impacts and adaptation includes:

ul.li: assessment of impacts of Europe's changing climate: a report published in 2004, which will be updated in 2008;
climate change state and impact indicators (global and European temperature and greenhouse gas concentrations in the atmosphere) as part of the EEA core set of indicators;
analysis of vulnerability of specific regions to climate change, see our 'Vulnerability and adaptation to climate change in Europe' report (2005);
analysis of climate change and water adaptation issues, including an overview of countries' adaptation actions;
methodologies to calculate the costs of climate change impacts and adaptation to climate change.

source.p: The EEA's work also supports the development of long-term strategies to mitigate and adapt to climate change through future outlooks and scenarios studies in the horizon 2020–2050, for example:

ul.li: analysis of long term greenhouse gas emissions and climate change impacts;
an assessment of possible greenhouse gas emission reduction pathways made feasible by global action and a transition to a low-carbon energy system in Europe by 2030;
analysis of projected changes in European air quality up to 2030, and of the possible benefits of climate policies on air quality.

source.p: Climate change is also one of the priority areas adressed by EEA in integrated assessments, in particular:

li.div: state and outlook reports on the European environment (see SOER 2005);
assessments of pan-European environment; see key messages on climate change from the Fourth assessment of the pan-European environment, published in 2007 (see presentation of the report in video).

trans-unit.source: Land use is leading to unprecedented changes in landscapes, ecosystems and the environment. Urban areas and related infrastructure are the fastest growing land consumers, mainly at the expense of productive agricultural land. Rural landscapes are changing due to agriculture intensification, land abandonment and forest exploitation. Coastal and mountain areas are undergoing profound spatial reorganisations to accommodate intensive tourism and leisure activities.
trans-unit.target: Land use is leading to unprecedented changes in landscapes, ecosystems and the environment. Urban areas and related infrastructure are the fastest growing land consumers, mainly at the expense of productive agricultural land. Rural landscapes are changing due to agriculture intensification, land abandonment and forest exploitation. Coastal and mountain areas are undergoing profound spatial reorganisations to accommodate intensive tourism and leisure activities.

source.p: Activities such as agriculture, forestry, transport and housing use land and alter its natural state and functions. Many environmental problems are rooted in the use of land; it leads to climate change, biodiversity loss and the pollution of water, soils and air. The impacts can be direct, e.g. the destruction of natural habitats and landscapes, or indirect, e.g. soil-sealing and deforestation enhancing flood risks. Climate change leads to desertification, changes in land cover and flash floods, amongst others.

With 75 % of Europe's population living in cities, urban land-use issues are currently of key importance. However, management of agricultural land and its multiple functions — food production, nature conservation, leisure and housing — is equally important. The increased land-take for urbanisation occurs mainly at the expense of agricultural land. During 1990–2000, of all areas converted to artificial land-use, 48 % were arable land or under permanent crops and 36 % were pasture or mixed farmland. Growth in transport has boosted land-take by transport infrastructure.

Mountains and uplands, the water tanks of Europe, are being abandoned by traditional users such as shepherds, to be replaced by skiers. Forest management has had to adapt to the global economic demand for timber production.

Coasts are being converted to man-made artificial surfaces at an even faster pace. Population sizes along Europe's coasts are continuously increasing, sometimes even faster than in inland areas. Tourism appears to be the most important maritime activity especially in southern countries and also those on the Baltic Sea, such as Poland and Finland. This activity has a very high spatial and seasonal impact; tourism flows affect the whole of Europe.

Coasts are being urbanised at an accelerating speed. Population densities in coastal regions are, on average, 10 % higher than their inland equivalent. The conversion of natural areas on the coast to artificial surfaces is growing at an even faster rate than population density. Housing (mostly secondary housing in many areas), services, recreation and transport infrastructure are the main causes.
Read more about Europe's land-use trends.

trans-unit.source: For the first time in human history, more people are living in towns and cities than in rural areas. Europe is one of the most urbanised continents. Approximately 75 % of its population lives in urban areas; by 2020, this will be 80 %. As a result, the demand for land in and around cities is becoming acute; urban sprawl is re-shaping landscapes and affecting people's quality of life and the environment as never before. Urban planning and management have risen high on the political agenda, with transport and housing as crucial challenges.
trans-unit.target: For the first time in human history, more people are living in towns and cities than in rural areas. Europe is one of the most urbanised continents. Approximately 75 % of its population lives in urban areas; by 2020, this will be 80 %. As a result, the demand for land in and around cities is becoming acute; urban sprawl is re-shaping landscapes and affecting people's quality of life and the environment as never before. Urban planning and management have risen high on the political agenda, with transport and housing as crucial challenges.

source.p: Urban development has a strong European dimension. Cities interact with and influence the surrounding land, thus affecting the environment of a much broader area. Their development is also driven by external factors such as demographic change, the need for mobility, globalisation and climate change. Decreasing household sizes and an ageing population are expected to enhance environmental pressures over the next decades. The further development of information, communication services and technology brings new important qualitative changes to urban systems.

Cities and towns act as engines for progress, often driving much of our cultural, intellectual, educational and technological achievements and innovations. However, today's trend of new, low-density approaches to urban development results in increased consumption of energy, resources, transport and land, thereby raising greenhouse gas emissions and air and noise pollution to levels that often exceed the legal or recommended human safety limits.

Overall consumption, energy use, water use and waste generation go along with a growing number of urban households. The EEA's report on urban sprawl shows that more than a quarter of the European Union's territory has been directly affected by urban land use: between 1990 and 2000 an area five times that of Greater London has been consigned to urban sprawl. This has primarily occurred on former agricultural land, resulting in the loss of important ecosystem services, such as food production, flood protection and biological diversity.

The ecological footprint concept indicates how much land and water area an individual, city or country requires to produce the resources it consumes and to absorb the waste it produces. Greater London's ecological footprint, for instance, is 293 times its own area, twice the size of the United Kingdom.

Air pollution in Europe 1990–2004 showed that despite reductions of emissions, high concentrations of fine particulates and ground-level ozone are still causing problems in many cities and surrounding areas. Fine particulate matter is now generally recognised to be the main threat to human health from air pollution. The World Health Organization (WHO) estimates that about 100 000 deaths a year could be linked to ambient air pollution in cities in Europe, shortening life expectancy by a year on average.

A major cause of air pollution and noise problems is the increase of motorised traffic which also leads to a reduction of available green and quiet space in city centres. This causes people to move out of the city into the suburbs and hinterland. The new, low-density urban areas lead to greater individual transport use which exacerbates existing problems.

div.p: The negative environmental effects of our consumption do not occur only in Europe, but also in other regions of the world, mainly as a result of the resource extraction, production, processing and transportation in other regions of the goods we consume in Europe, but also of our personal travel and tourist activities.

div.div: Common buzzard
G. Whitlow

div.p: Bald eagles in Florida (1952), river otters in England (late 1950s), mink in Michigan (mid-1960s), pheasants, eagles and ospreys in Sweden (1960s), fish consumers in Japan (1960s), herring gulls in Michigan (1970), western gulls in California (early 1980s), alligators in Florida (1980s), oysters in France (1980s), seals in northern Europe (1988), dolphins in the Mediterranean (early 1990s), and sperm counts in men worldwide (1992). Pharmaceutical residues from humans and farm animals, POP contamination in Great Lakes and in the Baltic Sea and air pollution from sulphur dioxide. These are only a few of the signals that are driving public concerns about the impacts of unsafe and unhealthy environments on ecosystems and human health.

div.div: Forest

div.p: Our economies are based on the use and consumption of natural resources. And it is not just industry - we all consume resources in our homes, through personal travel and our food and drink.

The most environmentally significant resources are materials, energy and land. Some resources, such as forests and fish, are renewable. Others, such as oil and land, are not, and will eventually run out.
Read the snapshot or main article for an overview, or go to the detailed sub sections.

trans-unit.source: Concern for future generations is a key prerequisite of sustainable development policies at global, European, national and local levels. Long-term policy objectives are at the heart of many international conventions and protocols that address problems of global environmental change. Long-term policy objectives also underpin key environmental policies of the European Union and its Member States. Scenarios support strategic planning and decision-making, and can help to test the implications and robustness of different policies. Equally important, they allow for profound stakeholder participation, enabling the representation of conflicting opinions and world views.

Scenarios support strategic planning and decision-making, and can help to test the implications and robustness of different policies. source.p: Environmental governance benefits from a dense web of international agreements and institutions. The most prominent long-term environmental policy frameworks are the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), the Convention on Biodiversity and the Millennium Development Goals. Mid- to long-term policy objectives underpin various international environmental conventions, for example the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer and its Montreal Protocol on Substances that Deplete the Ozone Layer and the Stockholm Convention on Persistent Organic Pollutants (POPs).

The European Union's Sustainable Development Strategy (SDS) sets out a plan to consistently tackle seven key mid- to long-term challenges of sustainable development, such as climate change, clean energy and sustainable transport and sustainable consumption and production. A number of European directives explicitly follow long-term objectives, especially in the area of climate change and energy policy. Similar developments can be observed in the EU Member States — several have institutionalised foresight programmes within their national administrations.

Long-term planning is less advanced in South Eastern Europe and the countries of Eastern Europe, the Caucasus and Central Asia, where the focus is more on reforming environmental policies, laws and regulations and strengthening compliance. However, initiatives are underway, to help avoid conflicts around scarce natural resources and also to support overall sustainable use and protection of natural resources (see the examples provided in the overview of forward-looking studies).

td.p:
Location of the EEA see map:
From Copenhagen Central station (Hovedbanegården)
The following buses go to Kongens Nytorv:
1A (towards Hellerup). Departs from Tietgensbro, a bridge at the rear part of the station. There are stairs from the platforms up to the bridge.
15 (towards Østerbro/Ryparken). Departs from the entrance facing Berntorffsgade and Tivoli.
The travel time is around 15 minutes. You need a 2 zone ticket (DKK 19) which can be obtained at the counter in the station, ticket machines or from the bus driver. For a detailed trip plan you can use www.rejseplanen.dk.
You can also walk from the central station to the Agency by following the main pedestrian street. It takes approx. 20 minutes.
From the airport by Metro

There is a direct Metro connection from Copenhagen Airport to Kongens Nytorv. You can find the airport Metro station by walking straight ahead from the baggage reclaim exit to the main lobby in terminal 3. Do not deviate right to taxis or left to busses or down to regional trains. Just go straight ahead and up the stairs or elevator following the Metro signs. The travel time to Kongens Nytorv is approx. 15 minutes. The trains depart with few minute intervals. You need a 3 zone ticket (DKK 28.50). It can be purchased from the ticket machines. For a detailed trip plan you can use www.rejseplanen.dk or www.m.dk/en/welcome/route.htm.

For more frequent usage of Copenhagen public transportation, you may purchase a ticket allowing multiple trips (ten-trip ticket).
From the airport by taxi
It takes approx. 25 minutes, price: approx. DKK 200.00

trans-unit.source: Land-use planning and management are essential to better reconcile land use with environmental concerns. It is a challenge that involves various policy levels and different sectors. Monitoring and mediating the negative environmental consequences of land use while sustaining the production of essential resources is a major priority of policy-makers around the world.
trans-unit.target: Land-use planning and management are essential to better reconcile land use with environmental concerns. It is a challenge that involves various policy levels and different sectors. Monitoring and mediating the negative environmental consequences of land use while sustaining the production of essential resources is a major priority of policy-makers around the world.

source.p: In 1999, the European Spatial Development Perspective (ESDP) resulted in European policy orientations for territorial balance and cohesion, improved competitiveness, access to markets and knowledge, as well as wiser management of natural and cultural resources. More recently, integrated spatial development has been addressed by the Territorial Agenda of the EU that aims at mobilising the potential of European regions and cities for sustainable economic growth and more jobs.

Land-use planning and management decisions are usually made at local or regional level. However, the European Commission has a role to play in ensuring Member States take environmental concerns into account in their land-use development plans. The goals are:

ul.li: to analyse the environmental impact of proposed developments;
to improve the geographic information flow about land-use issues;
to develop and implement European urban environment strategy;
to improve the planning, management and use of Europe's coastal zones.

source.p: European economies depend on natural resources, including raw materials and space (land resources). The EU thematic strategy on the sustainable use of natural resources includes space as a resource. It applies to areas of land and maritime space that are needed for production purposes (e.g. minerals, timber, food) and for various socio-economic activities. These interests are often competing for the same territorial resource.

Efforts to modify land-use practices to reduce non-point pollution of air and water include integrated river basin management and, in particular, the Nitrates Directive. Flooding caused by the construction of impervious surfaces (e.g. buildings and roads) and provoked by extreme weather events is addressed by a new European Floods Directive. The cross-cutting nature of land use is also emphasised by the EU rural development and regional policies.

The UNFCCC Kyoto Protocol promotes among others practices that reduce emissions of methane and nitrous oxide from agricultural land. EU policies on climate change adaptation are directly relevant to current and future land-use practices and economic sectors depending on this.

trans-unit.source: Sustainable urban development figures prominently in the EU's policies on environment, regional development, health and transport. Legislation, such as the ambient air quality and environmental noise directives, also targets cities. With its policies, the EU aims to strengthen the responsibilities of cities on the basis of the subsidiarity principle, which requires that matters are handled by the lowest competent level. The local and the European levels become, however, more and more interwoven, as do environmental, social and economic issues. Europe's future urban policy therefore has to find ways for more integrated and effective management between the various policy levels.

The local and the European levels become, however, more and more interwoven, as do environmental, social and economic issues. Europe's future urban policy therefore has to find ways for more integrated and effective management between the various policy levels.

source.p: Following the process from the Green Paper on the Urban Environment (1990), EU adopted the Thematic Strategy on the Urban Environment in 2006. This aims for better implementation of existing EU environmental policies and legislation at the local level through exchange of experience and good practice between Europe's local authorities. Guidance on integrated environmental management and sustainable urban transport planning are part of this.

Additional measures are linked to the implementation of the EU Directives on Ambient Air Quality and Environmental Noise. The Green Paper towards a new culture for urban mobility (2007) opens a debate for a new urban transport culture centered on a joint effort to make towns and cities greener and less polluted as well as safe and more accessible for all citizens.

The EU regional policy is an important driver for urban environment. The Communication Cohesion Policy and cities: the urban contribution to growth and jobs in the regions is designed to help national, regional and city authorities in the preparation of the new round of cohesion policy programmes.

The EU Member States highlighted the territorial importance of urban policy for Europe when adopting the Territorial Agenda of the European Union and the Leipzig Charter on Sustainable European Cities during their informal ministerial meeting in Leipzig in 2007. They agreed on continuous work under the presidencies and developed an implementation plan.

Numerous local authorities developed their Local Agenda 21 strategies and action plans. The Aalborg Charter is one of the most famous policy statements for local sustainable development signed by more than 2 500 local and regional authorities. The Sustainable Cities and Towns Campaign aims to help local governments across Europe to mainstream sustainability best practice.

trans-unit.source: Snapshot of why household consumption matters
trans-unit.target: Snapshot of why household consumption matters

source.p: Over the last ten years new economic and social trends have changed our personal patterns of consumption in ways that are having direct and indirect impacts on the environment.

Economic growth and globalisation, fewer people living in a household, the ageing population, technological breakthroughs such as mobile phones and the internet, and our growing desire for ownership and personal freedom, are all contributing to a rise in household consumption.
Our increased use of energy and materials is depleting natural resources, causing pollution and climate change through the emission of greenhouse gases (GHGs), and creating more and more waste.

Although there have been advances in making technologies for our homes and our cars more efficient, these have been counteracted by the steady rise in energy consumption, for example in the number of car and plane kilometres that we travel.
Natural resources such as sand, wood and especially land are under pressure because we are replacing our existing houses with new and larger ones.
Because much of what we consume comes from outside Europe, we have a global responsibility not to damage the environment, and to find ways of making our consumption patterns more sustainable.
These are some facts about household consumption:

ul.li: In the 1960s an average European grocery had 2,000 product lines. A modern supermarket has more than 15,000.
The consumption of bottled water per person increased in all European countries during the 1990s. Mineral water has to be transported long distances and generates large amounts of packaging waste.
Between 1990 and 2002, household consumption expenditure in the EU15 Member States increased by almost a third to over 12,000 Euros per person on average.
Households are one of the largest energy consumers in the EU, accounting for 26.2% of total energy consumption in 2001, compared with 27.7% for industrial use.
Space heating is by far the largest household energy end-use in the EU (70%), followed by water heating (14%) and electric appliances and lighting (12%).
Water metering has contributed to cutting household water use to less than 25% of total water use in Europe.

Every year we produce around 5.5-7 million tonnes of electronic waste - computers, mobile phones, TVs and other electronic devices - and this figure is increasing by 3-5% annually. Disposal of electronic waste leads to serious hazards from carcinogenic substances which can leach through to soil and groundwater.

Passenger cars have generally become more energy-efficient, but the growth in transport demand and the increased use of heavy and relatively fuel-inefficient cars such as sport utility vehicles (SUVs) have outweighed these improvements. Greenhouse gas emissions from transport have increased by about 20% in the past decade.
The number of households with two or more cars is on the increase, though approximately a quarter of EU households have none.
Around half of all passenger trips by car are less than 6 kilometres.

People are taking more and more trips by plane, with correspondingly higher fuel consumption and emissions. During the period 2000 to 2030 the share of air travel in Europe is projected to increase from 5.5% to 10.5%, while public transports share will fall from 9% to 6.5%.
The building of new roads has fragmented natural habitats and so affected biodiversity. Noise from traffic is also a problem across Europe.
Between 1990 and 1998, 10 hectares were taken every day for motorway construction in the EU.

source.p: We now have strong evidence of links between air pollution and our health. Chemicals, artificial hormone-like substances, gases and particulate matter from fossil fuel burning and industrial processes, are in our air, water and soil, and it is widely believed that they are damaging peoples respiratory and cardiovascular systems, hormone functions and brain development.
Children are particularly affected by environment-related pollution. It makes their asthma symptoms worse and means that they are more vulnerable to certain types of cancer and brain disorders.

div.div: Section that examines how children are particularly affected by cancer.

source.p: Climate change, caused by emissions of greenhouse gases, is a clear risk to our health, with the increased likelihood of intense heatwaves, hot climate diseases, violent storms, floods and droughts.

div.div: How climate change has and will affect our health

source.p: Although in some cases the links between certain pollutants and health problems are beyond doubt, in others we dont have conclusive proof, because of the complexity of separating out all the different factors of age, gender, genetic make-up, geographical location, diet, even peoples income and education level.

Another difficulty is time: a persons health needs to be studied over their whole life cycle. We may find that the combined long-term and cumulative exposure to chemicals and pollutants in food, air, water and consumer products will constitute a new risk - the cocktail effect.
These are some key facts about the environment and health:

ul.li: Air pollution is the environmental factor with the greatest impact on health in Europe.
The air pollutants that affect the respiratory system are ozone, nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxide, and particulate matter.
20 million Europeans suffer from respiratory problems.
In Europe, the cost to society of asthma has been estimated at 3 thousand million Euros per year.
Allergic disorders including asthma are relatively less common in Eastern Europe, despite levels of many air pollutants being higher there than in Western Europe.
Asthma is now the most common respiratory disease in western European children. On average, 7% of European children aged 4-10 have problems with asthma.
Research shows that children who grow up in areas with atmospheric pollution are twice as likely to develop reduced lung function when they grow up as children from rural areas.

Respiratory health improves when air quality improves. When changes were made in transport and community behaviour during the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta, hospital admissions of children with acute asthma symptoms fell by 41.6% during the period of the games.
The naturally occurring radioactive gas radon is responsible for 21,000 cases of lung cancers per year in the USA, and around 9,000 cases per year in Europe.
Approximately 80-90% of all skin cancers can be related to ultra-violet (UV) radiation from the sun.

Environmental pollution may have an effect on gender ratios. After the explosion in the chemical plant at Seveso in Italy in 1976 which spread dioxin over the surrounding area, 48 girls and 26 boys were born to the most exposed families during the 7 subsequent years.
Human sperm quality has declined markedly over the past 50 years, a phenomenon that may be related to chemicals, pesticides and/or natural hormone-like substances in the environment.
Climate change means that intense summer heat is becoming more common. The summer heat waves of 2003 resulted in more than 20,000 excess deaths in Europe.
Increasingly heavy rainfall is making flash floods more common.
We are likely to see more frequent droughts which will decrease the water supply and so increase the risk of water and food-borne diseases.
With rising temperatures, tick-borne diseases have been reaching epidemic proportions in many parts of Europe, and localised outbreaks of malaria are expected.

Wildlife health provides warning signs of how humans may be affected by environmental pollution. For example, marine predators such as seals, whales, dolphins and polar bears have been shown to have high levels of pollutant residues in their bodies that have been obtained through the food chain and are causing infertility, immunodeficiency and tissue malformation.

Pharmaceuticals can affect wildlife as well as humans. Populations of vultures in India and Pakistan have declined by more than 95% since 1997 as a result of exposure to diclofenac, a widely-used painkiller and anti-inflammatory drug. The birds are exposed to the drug when they feed on the carcasses of farm animals which have been treated with the drug.

Research shows that children who grow up in areas with atmospheric pollution are twice as likely to develop reduced lung function when they grow up as children from rural areas.

Respiratory health improves when air quality improves. When changes were made in transport and community behaviour during the 1996 Olympics in Atlanta, hospital admissions of children with acute asthma symptoms fell by 41.6% during the period of the games.
The naturally occurring radioactive gas radon is responsible for 21,000 cases of lung cancers per year in the USA, and around 9,000 cases per year in Europe.
Approximately 80-90% of all skin cancers can be related to ultra-violet (UV) radiation from the sun.

Environmental pollution may have an effect on gender ratios. After the explosion in the chemical plant at Seveso in Italy in 1976 which spread dioxin over the surrounding area, 48 girls and 26 boys were born to the most exposed families during the 7 subsequent years.
Human sperm quality has declined markedly over the past 50 years, a phenomenon that may be related to chemicals, pesticides and/or natural hormone-like substances in the environment.
Climate change means that intense summer heat is becoming more common. The summer heat waves of 2003 resulted in more than 20,000 excess deaths in Europe.
Increasingly heavy rainfall is making flash floods more common.
We are likely to see more frequent droughts which will decrease the water supply and so increase the risk of water and food-borne diseases.
With rising temperatures, tick-borne diseases have been reaching epidemic proportions in many parts of Europe, and localised outbreaks of malaria are expected.

Wildlife health provides warning signs of how humans may be affected by environmental pollution. For example, marine predators such as seals, whales, dolphins and polar bears have been shown to have high levels of pollutant residues in their bodies that have been obtained through the food chain and are causing infertility, immunodeficiency and tissue malformation.

Pharmaceuticals can affect wildlife as well as humans. Populations of vultures in India and Pakistan have declined by more than 95% since 1997 as a result of exposure to diclofenac, a widely-used painkiller and anti-inflammatory drug. The birds are exposed to the drug when they feed on the carcasses of farm animals which have been treated with the drug.

source.p: We use natural resources in many of our daily activities - by eating, drinking, wearing clothes, using our electric and electronic appliances, heating and lighting our homes, and driving our cars. But what are the effects of our consumption? And can we go on consuming at our current rate?
The uncomfortable reality is that the wealthier our societies become, and the more of us there are, the more resources we use and the greater the pressures on our environment.

One obvious problem is the environments capacity to go on providing the resources we need. The Earth is a closed materials system and although some materials such as forests and fish are renewable, others such as metals, oil and land, are not.

Another issue is the environments ability to absorb the effects of our consumption - the discharge of chemical pollutants and harmful emissions. For example, the greenhouse gases given off from the burning of fossil fuels are already changing our climate.

What we need to do is break the link between economic growth and increased pressures on the environment. In the last twenty years many EU countries have started using resources more efficiently, but our overall consumption has not decreased.

If future generations are to inherit a world where there is enough to go round and which has not been environmentally degraded, we may have to take radical action to change our lifestyles and consumption behaviour.
Here are some facts about the sustainable use and management of natural resources:

ul.li: Over the next fifty years the total consumption of natural resources by the world population is projected to be between double and five times what it is now.
The global population is expected to grow by 50% over the next 50 years.
In the 2nd half of the 20th century, global trade volumes grew by a factor of 6 to 8 for raw materials and as much as 40 for manufactured goods.
Current materials consumption in industrialised countries is between 31 and 74 tonnes per person per year.
Most of the energy we use in Europe comes from fossil fuels. Each year almost 4 tonnes are consumed per person in the 15 original member countries of the EU and about half that is imported.
However, fossil fuel-related emissions of air pollutants have come down over the last ten years, thanks to the use of cleaning up equipment.
Estimates show that the mid-depletion point of worldwide crude oil reserves could be reached within the next 10-20 years.
Extraction of metals leads to contamination of soils and destruction of landscape, harm to biodiversity and natural water cycles, high energy consumption and the largest waste stream in Europe.
Extraction of construction minerals (sand, gravel, clay, limestone and natural stones) causes noise and air pollution on top of most of the problems encountered with the extraction of metals.
Water resources are under threat from increasing population, intensive agriculture, rapid urbanisation, growing tourism and leisure activities, and the lack of proper supply and treatment facilities.
It takes approximately 1,000 litres of water to produce 1 kg of wheat; 2,700 litres of water to produce 1 kg of eggs; 13,500 litres of water to produce 1 kg of beef
If the entire global population were to adopt a western-style diet, about 75% more water would be needed for food production.
Considerable progress has been made in reducing industrial and urban chemical discharges, and contamination of drinking and bathing water is now largely under control.
The picture is less positive with agriculture, however, and high concentrations of pesticides and heavy metals can still be found in many European waters.
The seas around Europe provide about 10% of the worlds fish catches, but many of our stocks are now considered to be in a critical state because of over-fishing.
In most European countries forest area is increasing on average by about half a million hectares a year.

Tree and soil quality have improved to a certain extent because of the decrease in atmospheric pollution from industrial emissions of sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxide. But the continuing acidification of soils and climate change need to be addressed.
Land is under threat from urbanisation, agricultural activities, and contamination from mines, industry and landfills.
The rate of soil regeneration in Europe is only about 5 cm in 500 years.
During the last twenty years built-up areas have expanded in Europe by 20%, in contrast to the population size which has only increased by 6%.
In 2000 Germanys increase in urban areas and infrastructure was 130 hectares a day.
Agriculture has considerable impact on the environment as regards land use. More land has been converted to cropland since 1945 than in the 18th and 19th centuries put together.

trans-unit.source: Policy events in recent years have led to a shift in policy focus towards environmental sustainability, competitiveness and security of energy supply. The ongoing public debate around renewable energy sources, new technologies, energy efficiency, greenhouse gas emissions and climate change has also placed energy at the top of the policy agenda, both in Europe and globally.
trans-unit.target: Policy events in recent years have led to a shift in policy focus towards environmental sustainability, competitiveness and security of energy supply. The ongoing public debate around renewable energy sources, new technologies, energy efficiency, greenhouse gas emissions and climate change has also placed energy at the top of the policy agenda, both in Europe and globally.

source.p: In January 2007, the European Commission proposed an integrated energy and climate change package to cut greenhouse gas emissions. The energy package aimed at establishing a new Energy Policy for Europe to combat climate change and boost the EU’s energy security and competitiveness.
The package is based on three main pillars:

ul.li: A true internal energy market. This aims to give energy users real choices and to trigger the huge investments needed in energy. Since 1 July 2007 all European citizens have been able to freely choose their electricity and gas supplier. The European Commission will have to ensure fair and dynamic competition in all Member States.

Accelerating the shift to low carbon energy. This aims to maintain the EU’s position as a world leader in renewable energy, proposing that at least 20 % of the EU’s energy needs shall be met by renewable energy sources by 2020.

Energy efficiency. This aims to save 20 % of primary energy consumption by 2020, reiterating a previous objective of the Commission. It also proposes increasing the use of fuel-efficient vehicles for transport; tougher standards and better labelling on appliances; improved energy performance of the EU’s existing buildings; and improved efficiency of heat and electricity generation, transmission and distribution.

source.p: In March 2007, the European Council accepted most of these proposals and agreed on actions to develop a sustainable integrated European climate and energy policy. The resulting policy pursues the following three objectives:

ul.li: Increasing security of supply;
Ensuring the competitiveness of European economies and the availability of affordable energy;
Promoting environmental sustainability and combating climate change.

source.p: To meet these objectives, in March 2007 the European Council adopted a comprehensive energy Action Plan for the period 2007–2009, comprising priority actions in the following areas: an internal market for gas and electricity; security of supply; international energy policy; energy efficiency and renewable energies; and energy technologies.
In January 2008, the European Commission presented further proposals to fight climate change and promote renewable energy, including legally enforceable targets for Member States.
