trans-unit.source: Scenarios and forward studies — EEA activities
trans-unit.target: Scenarios and forward studies — EEA activities

trans-unit.source: The EEA assesses long-term prospects for Europe's environment and the consequences of key-policy choices using various methodological approaches. The aims are to add value to current policy discussions, by consistently producing information with a broader and longer-term perspective, and to help organise the European environmental information systems to encompass information on future trends. The EEA also contributes knowledge and expertise to scenario-based assessments at pan-European and global levels, such as the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment or UNEP's GEO-4 scenarios.
trans-unit.target: The EEA assesses long-term prospects for Europe's environment and the consequences of key-policy choices using various methodological approaches. The aims are to add value to current policy discussions, by consistently producing information with a broader and longer-term perspective, and to help organise the European environmental information systems to encompass information on future trends. The EEA also contributes knowledge and expertise to scenario-based assessments at pan-European and global levels, such as the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment or UNEP's GEO-4 scenarios.

source.p: EEA's scenarios activities contribute to the long-term perspective of the European 'state of the environment' report that is published every five years. In 2005, the European environment — State and outlook report and the complementary European environment outlook report were published addressing a range of environmental concerns and their common driving forces in an integrated way and highlighting prospects for Europe's environment to the year 2030 and beyond. A similar exercise is due to be published in 2010.

Outlooks are also a component of regular assessment processes, e.g. greenhouse gas emissions and indicator-reporting processes of the EEA. Outlook studies and indicators are analysed on a regular basis. The review of quantitative models is another frequent exercise.

PRELUDE (PRospective Environmental analysis of Land Use Development in Europe) uses an innovative mix of illustration, text and state-of-the-art models to simulate five contrasting future environmental scenarios for a Europe affected by changing patterns of land use, climate change, agriculture and demographics. A new area for scenario-based assessments is the analysis of ecosystem services.

The EEA is also involved in scenario processes at the pan-European and international level. The pan-European environment: glimpses into an uncertain future investigates the key driving forces and uncertainties of future environmental changes for the pan-European region. EEA also contributed to the UNEP Global Environment Outlook 4 report and the Millennium Ecosystem Assessment.
The EEA also helps capacity-building for scenario development in its member countries, with regular outreach and training workshops.

trans-unit.source: To understand the relationship between land use and environmental impacts, information is needed at different scales — global, European and national. Land-use data are also a prerequisite for spatial planning at local and regional level. EEA activities focus mainly on Europe's landscape and spatial change assessments by using land and ecosystem accounting tools and geographic information system analysis. EEA has also been tasked to develop an environmental data centre for land use as a contribution to a shared environmental information system for Europe (SEIS).
trans-unit.target: To understand the relationship between land use and environmental impacts, information is needed at different scales — global, European and national. Land-use data are also a prerequisite for spatial planning at local and regional level. EEA activities focus mainly on Europe's landscape and spatial change assessments by using land and ecosystem accounting tools and geographic information system analysis. EEA has also been tasked to develop an environmental data centre for land use as a contribution to a shared environmental information system for Europe (SEIS).

source.p: The EEA supports the spatial requirements of EU thematic strategies on marine systems and soils, amongst others, and pays particular attention to land-use changes in ecologically sensitive areas and protection of soils.

The European Topic Centre on Land Use and Spatial Information (ETC-LUSI) provides the EEA with technical support in developing relevant indicators, carrying out the Corine land cover inventories, land and ecosystem accounting (LEAC) applications and geospatial analysis.

The main EEA data source is the Corine land cover data set that has been produced for 1990, 2000 and 2006. It is based on established cooperation with the member countries and the Global Monitoring for Environment and Security (GMES) system.

Based on spatial information, the land accounts produced by the EEA provide assessments of the magnitude of the various types of change and, at the same time, of their distribution over the European territory.

Land use is often part of analyses of other topics, such as climate change adaptation, river basin management, prospective analysis, consumption and production patterns, coastal zones and the urban environment.
The EEA has also developed interactive maps and multimedia products including a land cover data viewer. Land-related terms can be checked in Eionet's GEMET Thesaurus.
Looking into the future, PRELUDE (PRospective Environmental analysis of Land Use Development in Europe) is an interactive tool presenting a set of five different land-use scenarios for Europe.

trans-unit.source: The EEA supports EU urban-related policies by developing databases and assessments on the land-use dynamics of urban areas (e.g. urban sprawl), sustainable urban management issues and specific pollution matters such as noise and air quality. This is done through close cooperation with the major city networks and other stakeholders, which includes joint actions and information exchange.
trans-unit.target: The EEA supports EU urban-related policies by developing databases and assessments on the land-use dynamics of urban areas (e.g. urban sprawl), sustainable urban management issues and specific pollution matters such as noise and air quality. This is done through close cooperation with the major city networks and other stakeholders, which includes joint actions and information exchange.

source.p: Based on the Corine land cover data the EEA developed a set of analytical units — Urban Morphological Zones (UMZ). The data show the extent of urban land-take in Europe, where sprawl happens and how it is shaped. Combined with other Corine land cover data on land-use changes, green areas and Natura 2000 sites, the influence of cities on natural and other land types can be analysed, as well as quality of life and population densities.

A tool is being developed to integrate EEA spatial data with other socio-economic and functional urban data like the Urban audit database (Eurostat and DG REGIO) and European Spatial Planning Observatory Network (ESPON).
Following the Air Quality Framework Directive, EEA collects data on ambient air quality in European agglomerations (around 1 700 cities) in AirBase.

The Directive on Environmental Noise requires Member States to deliver noise exposure data in major agglomerations. The European Commission established a database of the reported information, supported by EEA reviews.
Urban wastewater treatment data are available in the Water Information System for Europe (WISE).

The EEA Report Urban sprawl in Europe — The ignored challenge gives the first comprehensive overview of the urban sprawl problem, analysing impacts and drivers, such as transport and pricing policies. When socio-economic and functional data are further integrated, it will be possible to explore these relationships in more detail.
Urban assessments are also included in the EEA's regular air pollution assessments, its state and outlook reports, e.g. the State and outlook 2005 report, and other reports of a cross-cutting nature.

Together with the major European city networks and stakeholders, the EEA is also exploring the interrelationships between urban and European policy-making under current and future challenges such as climate change, changing consumption patterns and demographic changes.

source.p: The way we consume has both direct and indirect impacts on the environment in Europe and in other regions of the world.

Household consumption forms an important part of the production-consumption chain as it is consumers who make the final choice as to which goods and services to buy. Even though the environmental pressures caused by each household are relatively small compared to those caused by production activities, the millions of households in Europe combined are a major contributor to environmental problems such as climate change, air and water pollution, land use and waste generation.

For example, the use of energy in our homes and our dependence on cars is causing air pollution and increased emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) that lead to climate change. Also, we are creating more and more waste from household activities. But in addition to those and other direct effects, consumption also indirectly leads to environmental impacts from the production, processing and transportation of the goods we consume.

Despite the advances that have been made, for example in introducing more ecologically efficient production methods and reducing harmful emissions from vehicles, these have been offset by the rapidly rising consumption of goods and services.

And because much of what we consume comes from outside Europe, it is not only our own continents environment we are damaging. We have a global responsibility to find ways of building sustainability into our consumption patterns.

blockquote.p: Sustainable consumption is the use of goods and services that respond to basic needs and bring a better quality of life, while minimising the use of natural resources, toxic materials and emissions of waste and pollutants over the life cycle, so as not to jeopardise the needs of future generations.
Norwegian Ministry of Environment 1995 and 1995

source.p: Mapping our patterns of consumption is not straightforward. They vary from country to country, and even from person to person, and are shaped by a range of interdependent social, cultural, political and economic trends in Europe and the rest of the world.

In the last ten years we have seen major developments that have changed how and what we consume. One is economic growth, globalisation and the opening of markets. As we become wealthier, we consume more. Although millions of Europeans are still living in poverty and are partly excluded from our consumption society, the average European now has a higher income and a higher standard of living than in the past, and has access to products from all over the world.
One recent development is that households are getting smaller on average, and partly because of that we use more energy and water and generate more waste per person.

Technological breakthroughs such as the internet and mobile phone have theoretically opened the way to shopping and working from home, though it has not yet been possible to observe accompanying reductions in demand for transport.

We have also changed culturally and socially. Individualisation, the belief in the individual and the desire for ownership and personal freedom, means that by consuming, we can express ourselves through the goods and services we choose and can enjoy the feeling of personal freedom through, for example, our cars and plane travel.
In fact, our passion for cars is now so strong that many people are prepared to put up with pollution and congested roads rather than use alternative forms of transport.
source.h2: How household consumption affects the environment
source.p: The energy, materials and resources we use have direct and indirect impacts on the environment.

Generally speaking, the indirect environmental effects of consumption are higher than the direct ones. For example, when we prepare and eat food, the direct environmental effects of the cooking process are considerably less than the combined indirect effects of pollution and waste from the agricultural production, the industrial processing of the food and its transportation.

Many of the resources we need, such as fossil fuels and metals, are extracted in other parts of the world, and many goods consumed in Europe are now being produced in Asia, Latin America and Africa where labour is cheaper.

The emissions from the transport of those goods also takes place mainly outside Europe. The responsibility for these direct negative environmental effects from production activities in those regions therefore belongs to Europe.
In Europe itself many direct negative environmental effects of consumption such as air emissions from personal travel and waste from households are also increasing rapidly.
source.h2: The impact of food and drink consumption

blockquote.p: In the 1960s an average European grocery had 2,000 product lines. A modern supermarket has more than 15,000.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: Every stage of the food production chain - from growing crops, raising livestock or fish, to transportation and storage, manufacturing, distribution, purchasing, consumption, and dealing with waste - has environmental effects.

blockquote.p: When Swedish researchers compared the greenhouse gas emissions given off over the life cycle of four different meals with the same energy and protein content, they found that they ranged from 190g carbon dioxide-equivalent for a vegetarian meal with local ingredients to 1,800g for a meal containing meat, with most ingredients imported.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: Around a third of all the environmental impacts from households are related to food and drinks consumption. These include emissions to water, soil and air from livestock, agriculture and industry, overuse of fish resources and increased transport of food, but also waste from production processes.
At the other end of the chain, the shift to off-season fresh food, as well as to bottled water and convenience foods, has resulted in large streams of packaging waste.
More than two-thirds of packaging waste comes from food consumption.

blockquote.p: Households are one of the largest final energy consumers in the EU, accounting for 26.2% of total energy consumption in 2001, compared with 27.7% for industrial use.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: The demand for new housing is eroding the available land, and we are using more energy in our homes than we used to. We are buying, and frequently replacing, many more electric and electronic goods such as computers, DVDs and kitchen appliances. As a result, even though the goods we buy are more energy-efficient than they used to be, we are continuing to produce the same amount of emissions of GHGs and rising amounts of waste. Total energy use has increased because we now have more appliances.

blockquote.p: For washing machines, dishwashers and cold appliances like fridges and freezers, the average unit energy consumption fell by 21% between 1990 and 2002, but total energy consumption only fell by 2% as a result of increasing use of appliances.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: The picture for water use is more positive. Consumption by households is on average less than 25% of total water use in Europe and has actually decreased in all regions of Europe in the past decade. This reduction can be directly linked to the water pricing and metering measures put in place to ensure the price of water better reflects its true costs.

source.p: Higher disposable incomes, longer distances between home, work and school, more shopping and leisure activities, and deteriorating public transport which is becoming more and more expensive, are all factors in the shift towards the private car in recent decades. The number of households with two or more cars is on the rise, though approximately a quarter of EU households have none.

Europe has become a car-dominant society and growing energy consumption and emissions of GHGs from personal travel are increasingly contributing to climate change. The building of new roads has fragmented natural habitats and so affected biodiversity, and noise from traffic is also a problem across Europe.

div.div: Link to an interactive animation (click on the mindstretcher) that shows the impact in land use and GHG emissions of switching to biofuels.

blockquote.p: Between 1990 and 1998, 10 hectares were taken every day for motorway construction in the EU.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: Technologies such as hybrid cars and fuels cells may help to reduce emissions but as long as consumption keeps growing, the net benefit may continue to be overwhelmed by growth in demand.

There are other prices to pay for our excessive car use. Congestion makes urban areas less and less accessible and leads to significant costs in terms of delivery delays and lost working hours, not to mention raised stress levels.

blockquote.p: Around half of all passenger trips by car are less than 6 kilometres.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: Another growing cause for concern is the escalation in plane trips. People are tending to visit more remote destinations and are taking more short breaks outside and inside Europe, partly as a result of the current low air fares. Aviation now almost matches rail transport in terms of total passenger kilometres travelled, and it is currently growing much faster than the economy. The environmental concern is mainly based on the high level of aircraft fuel emissions, which contribute to climate change.

blockquote.p: During the period 2000 to 2030 the share of air travel in Europe is projected to increase from 5.5% to 10.5%, while public transports share will fall from 9% to 6.5%. This shift will bring about a corresponding increase in greenhouse gas emissions from passenger travel if no technological breakthroughs take place in the meantime.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: On the plus side of personal travel, the numbers of walkers and cyclists is on the increase, and high-speed trains are gaining market share in some countries and becoming a viable alternative to the car and plane for intercity traffic.

source.h2: What can be done to bend the trend
source.p: The first global political agreement on the need for sustainable consumption was made at the UN Conference on Environment and Development at Rio de Janeiro in 1992. In 2002 the World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg agreed to develop a framework of programmes on sustainable consumption and production, and there is commitment to strategies for sustainability at the EU and national levels.

Given the different types of consumer behaviour and influencing factors across Europe it is a complex challenge to design and implement suitable measures. Nevertheless public authorities at the global, EU, national, regional and local levels can influence the sustainability of consumption and production by providing a framework within which business and consumers can operate. The tools available include:

ul.li: legal and regulatory instruments (such as directives, laws and regulations)
market-based instruments (such as taxes and charges, tradable permits and subsidy removal)
enabling technological improvements
making information available.

source.p: In practice, the challenge is to implement the right combination of policy instruments that take different groups of consumers into account, in order to achieve the most sustainable results.

Business has an instrumental role in enabling and carrying out sustainable consumption and production. Operating within the framework provided by public authorities and meeting the demands of consumers, the challenge for business is to provide goods and services which are profitable and sustainable, when they are being both produced and consumed.
Europes consumers have arguably an important role to play since it is we who decide what goods and services to consume and in what amounts.

Provided that information on the environmental effects of the goods and services is available within the framework set by public authorities, and that prices are affordable, consumers can choose to buy goods and services that are sustainable through their life-cycle from production to consumption.
Other options for consumers include sustainable energy resources, modes of transport which have the least impact on the environment, reducing our use of water and generating less waste.

div.div: More information of what drives consumption of resources

target.p: The way we consume has both direct and indirect impacts on the environment in Europe and in other regions of the world.

Household consumption forms an important part of the production-consumption chain as it is consumers who make the final choice as to which goods and services to buy. Even though the environmental pressures caused by each household are relatively small compared to those caused by production activities, the millions of households in Europe combined are a major contributor to environmental problems such as climate change, air and water pollution, land use and waste generation.

For example, the use of energy in our homes and our dependence on cars is causing air pollution and increased emissions of greenhouse gases (GHGs) that lead to climate change. Also, we are creating more and more waste from household activities. But in addition to those and other direct effects, consumption also indirectly leads to environmental impacts from the production, processing and transportation of the goods we consume.

Despite the advances that have been made, for example in introducing more ecologically efficient production methods and reducing harmful emissions from vehicles, these have been offset by the rapidly rising consumption of goods and services.

And because much of what we consume comes from outside Europe, it is not only our own continents environment we are damaging. We have a global responsibility to find ways of building sustainability into our consumption patterns.

blockquote.p: Sustainable consumption is the use of goods and services that respond to basic needs and bring a better quality of life, while minimising the use of natural resources, toxic materials and emissions of waste and pollutants over the life cycle, so as not to jeopardise the needs of future generations.
Norwegian Ministry of Environment 1995 and 1995

target.p: Mapping our patterns of consumption is not straightforward. They vary from country to country, and even from person to person, and are shaped by a range of interdependent social, cultural, political and economic trends in Europe and the rest of the world.

In the last ten years we have seen major developments that have changed how and what we consume. One is economic growth, globalisation and the opening of markets. As we become wealthier, we consume more. Although millions of Europeans are still living in poverty and are partly excluded from our consumption society, the average European now has a higher income and a higher standard of living than in the past, and has access to products from all over the world.
One recent development is that households are getting smaller on average, and partly because of that we use more energy and water and generate more waste per person.

Technological breakthroughs such as the internet and mobile phone have theoretically opened the way to shopping and working from home, though it has not yet been possible to observe accompanying reductions in demand for transport.

We have also changed culturally and socially. Individualisation, the belief in the individual and the desire for ownership and personal freedom, means that by consuming, we can express ourselves through the goods and services we choose and can enjoy the feeling of personal freedom through, for example, our cars and plane travel.
In fact, our passion for cars is now so strong that many people are prepared to put up with pollution and congested roads rather than use alternative forms of transport.
target.h2: How household consumption affects the environment
target.p: The energy, materials and resources we use have direct and indirect impacts on the environment.

Generally speaking, the indirect environmental effects of consumption are higher than the direct ones. For example, when we prepare and eat food, the direct environmental effects of the cooking process are considerably less than the combined indirect effects of pollution and waste from the agricultural production, the industrial processing of the food and its transportation.

Many of the resources we need, such as fossil fuels and metals, are extracted in other parts of the world, and many goods consumed in Europe are now being produced in Asia, Latin America and Africa where labour is cheaper.

The emissions from the transport of those goods also takes place mainly outside Europe. The responsibility for these direct negative environmental effects from production activities in those regions therefore belongs to Europe.
In Europe itself many direct negative environmental effects of consumption such as air emissions from personal travel and waste from households are also increasing rapidly.
target.h2: The impact of food and drink consumption

blockquote.p: In the 1960s an average European grocery had 2,000 product lines. A modern supermarket has more than 15,000.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: Every stage of the food production chain - from growing crops, raising livestock or fish, to transportation and storage, manufacturing, distribution, purchasing, consumption, and dealing with waste - has environmental effects.

blockquote.p: When Swedish researchers compared the greenhouse gas emissions given off over the life cycle of four different meals with the same energy and protein content, they found that they ranged from 190g carbon dioxide-equivalent for a vegetarian meal with local ingredients to 1,800g for a meal containing meat, with most ingredients imported.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: Around a third of all the environmental impacts from households are related to food and drinks consumption. These include emissions to water, soil and air from livestock, agriculture and industry, overuse of fish resources and increased transport of food, but also waste from production processes.
At the other end of the chain, the shift to off-season fresh food, as well as to bottled water and convenience foods, has resulted in large streams of packaging waste.
More than two-thirds of packaging waste comes from food consumption.

blockquote.p: Households are one of the largest final energy consumers in the EU, accounting for 26.2% of total energy consumption in 2001, compared with 27.7% for industrial use.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: The demand for new housing is eroding the available land, and we are using more energy in our homes than we used to. We are buying, and frequently replacing, many more electric and electronic goods such as computers, DVDs and kitchen appliances. As a result, even though the goods we buy are more energy-efficient than they used to be, we are continuing to produce the same amount of emissions of GHGs and rising amounts of waste. Total energy use has increased because we now have more appliances.

blockquote.p: For washing machines, dishwashers and cold appliances like fridges and freezers, the average unit energy consumption fell by 21% between 1990 and 2002, but total energy consumption only fell by 2% as a result of increasing use of appliances.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: The picture for water use is more positive. Consumption by households is on average less than 25% of total water use in Europe and has actually decreased in all regions of Europe in the past decade. This reduction can be directly linked to the water pricing and metering measures put in place to ensure the price of water better reflects its true costs.

target.p: Higher disposable incomes, longer distances between home, work and school, more shopping and leisure activities, and deteriorating public transport which is becoming more and more expensive, are all factors in the shift towards the private car in recent decades. The number of households with two or more cars is on the rise, though approximately a quarter of EU households have none.

Europe has become a car-dominant society and growing energy consumption and emissions of GHGs from personal travel are increasingly contributing to climate change. The building of new roads has fragmented natural habitats and so affected biodiversity, and noise from traffic is also a problem across Europe.

div.div: Link to an interactive animation (click on the mindstretcher) that shows the impact in land use and GHG emissions of switching to biofuels.

blockquote.p: Between 1990 and 1998, 10 hectares were taken every day for motorway construction in the EU.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: Technologies such as hybrid cars and fuels cells may help to reduce emissions but as long as consumption keeps growing, the net benefit may continue to be overwhelmed by growth in demand.

There are other prices to pay for our excessive car use. Congestion makes urban areas less and less accessible and leads to significant costs in terms of delivery delays and lost working hours, not to mention raised stress levels.

blockquote.p: Around half of all passenger trips by car are less than 6 kilometres.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: Another growing cause for concern is the escalation in plane trips. People are tending to visit more remote destinations and are taking more short breaks outside and inside Europe, partly as a result of the current low air fares. Aviation now almost matches rail transport in terms of total passenger kilometres travelled, and it is currently growing much faster than the economy. The environmental concern is mainly based on the high level of aircraft fuel emissions, which contribute to climate change.

div.div: More information of what drives consumption of resources

source.p: The increase in asthma, the fall in sperm counts, the declining numbers of fish and bird species - these are only some of the public concerns that suggest there is a link between environmental quality and our health.

We now have evidence that air pollution and certain hazardous chemicals in air, food and water are contributors to environment-related diseases in particular circumstances. These include some types of cancer, respiratory diseases, allergies and asthma, cardiovascular disease, and neurological, reproductive and developmental disorders.
Climate change is bringing with it clear risks to Europeans safety, with the increasing prevalence of flash floods, severe forest fires and heat waves, and certain hot climate diseases.

And there are other unknown environment-related health threats to add to the list, such as the impact of electromagnetic and radio-frequency fields, and ecological imbalances that cause toxic algae to spread.

In disease studies, people who live in industrialised countries tend to be affected differently to people in developing countries, and there are differences between the east and west of Europe. In some Eastern European countries for example environment-related diseases tend to be mainly related to limited access to proper food, housing, health care and safe drinking water. In Western Europe on the other hand they are more to do with air pollution in urban areas and with chemicals in water and food.

Other factors that influence a persons risk of developing one of these diseases or disorders are their genes, their age, what they eat and drink, and socio-economic factors such as their level of income and education.
Children are especially vulnerable.

blockquote.p: On average, 7% of European children aged 4-10 have problems with asthma, which is partly linked to environmental factors, and among children aged 0-4 years, 1.8-6.4% of deaths from all causes were attributable to outdoor air pollution. There has also been a small but significant increase in childhood cancers since the mid 1980s.
EEA SOER Report 2005

source.p: Air pollution is the environmental factor with the greatest impact on health in Europe and there are many studies that show that respiratory health and quality of life both improve when air quality improves.
The air pollutants that affect the respiratory system are ozone, nitrogen oxides, sulphur dioxide, and particulate matter.

The breathing in of fine particulate matter (released into the air by the burning of fossil fuels, among other sources) significantly increases the numbers of deaths from cardiovascular and cardiopulmonary diseases. Exposure to particulate matter is also linked to increased frequency of chronic bronchitis, respiratory hospital admissions and restricted activity days.
Ground level ozone, one of the components of smog and produced through vehicle exhaust and industrial emissions, also has severe implications for respiratory health.

blockquote.p: In December 1952 dense smog - a mixture of fog and coal smoke - descended on London. Records from Londons hospitals showed that more than 2 000 people died from the exposure to air pollutants during one week, and there was strong pressure for this never to happen again. Another smog incident that occurred in 1962 with about 800 deaths further demonstrated the need for action.
Late lessons from early warnings

p.p: Although levels of particulate matter and ozone have both been reduced considerably since then, recent estimates indicate that 20 million Europeans suffer from respiratory problems. The European Commission Clean Air for Europe (CAFE) programme found that in 2000 around 350,000 people were dying prematurely due to outdoor pollution of fine particulate matter alone. This corresponds to an average loss of life expectancy of about 9 months for every EU citizen.

div.div: How early warning signs were not always acted upon quickly.

source.p: Research shows that children who grow up in areas with atmospheric pollution are twice as likely to develop reduced lung function when they grow up as children from rural areas, which is why more and more scientists and health-care professionals are now studying foetal life and early childhood.

Asthma is on the increase all over Europe and a large portion of this increase is in asthma in children. Asthmatics are particularly sensitive to air quality and several studies have shown a strong link between exposure to air pollution and the aggravation of asthma.

However, it seems that children do not initially become asthmatic because of air pollution, as can be shown by the fact that allergic disorders including asthma are relatively less common in Eastern Europe, despite levels of many air pollutants being higher there than in Western Europe. It is thought that asthma has many triggers including nutritional and genetic factors.

div.div: Section that details possible causes of asthma.

source.p: Until now, most research into air quality has concentrated on levels of pollution found outdoors. Yet European children spend 90% of their time indoors, and poor indoor air quality can cause a number of health problems including cancer, allergies, sleeping and concentration problems, and coughing, wheezing and asthma-like symptoms in children.

Indoor pollution comes from building materials, paints, furniture and carpets, the chemicals in cleaning agents, disinfectants and air cleaners, as well as open fires. Humidity indoors stimulates the development of biological pollutants such as mites, mould and bacteria, and increases the release of chemicals from building materials. Research has found respiratory problems including asthma in children from homes with visible damp and mould, and also where there is a combination of moisture, mould, tobacco smoke, gas stoves, and mites and allergens from pets.

div.div: Children spend more time indoors than they used to creating new health issues.

source.p: There are well-known cancer risks from the accidental release of radiation from nuclear power stations, but in fact around 80% of radiation comes from natural sources and has the same potentially damaging effects on our health as man-made radiation.

Uranium is a chemical element which is found naturally in soil, rocks and water. When it decays it forms radon, a radioactive gas, which seeps into buildings through the ground. Radon is easily absorbed into dust particles and when inhaled causes gene damage and mutations which can lead to lung cancer. There are studies suggesting that radon could also increase the risk of childhood leukaemia but there is no definite evidence of this.
Another type of radiation, ultra-violet (UV) radiation from the sun, has been shown to damage health. Approximately 80-90% of all skin cancers can be related to UV radiation.

div.div: The link between ionising radiation and cancer.
Lessons not learned from early experiences of radiation.

source.h2: Risks from chemicals in the environment
source.p: Chemical pollution comes from industry, agriculture, waste disposal and incineration and products used in the home.
Certain chemicals have detrimental effects on childrens neurodevelopment (their behaviour, memory or ability to learn):

ul.li: Mercury, which can be present in fish, is well known to result in attention problems, reduced learning ability and slightly reduced IQ in children.
Lead has been proven to affect neurodevelopment. The ban on leaded petrol has been very successful in lowering blood lead levels in children, but more data are currently being collected.

Prenatal exposure to PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyls, which are present in some pesticides, paints and plastics, among other substances) have been shown to have a negative effect on the childs cognitive processes, motor development and reflexes, and to interfere with the function of the thyroid hormone, which is crucial for normal neurodevelopment.

a.alt: Late lessons from North American lakes

div.a: Late lessons from North American lakes

div.div: Lessons learned from chemical pollution of the Great Lakes

source.p: A number of chemicals are suspected carcinogens, including PAH (polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons), which are given off when wood, coal, and diesel are burned.

Industrial chemicals and pesticides could be a factor behind the increase in endocrine disruption, in which the hormone-dependent functions in the body (embryonic development, sperm production, control of the menstrual cycle, the onset of puberty, among others) are affected.

Worldwide, semen quality has declined over the past 50 years. Although there is no clear link with chemicals in humans, there is a wealth of data showing that industrial chemicals, pesticides and natural hormone-like substances found in different types of food are interfering with the endocrine systems of birds, fish and amphibians.

div.div: How chemicals affect our health.
Historical lessons from the use of chemicals.

source.p: The summer heat waves of 2003 resulted in more than 20,000 excess deaths in Europe, and we are likely to see more frequent, intense summer heat in the years to come. Increasingly heavy rainfall is making flash floods more common, with the obvious risk to life, but there are also health-related side effects of living in flood-prone areas such as stress and depression. At the other extreme, droughts will decrease the water supply and so increase the possibility of water and food-borne diseases.

Rising temperatures mean that insects and parasites are spreading geographically. Tick-borne diseases are reaching epidemic proportions in many parts of Europe, and localised outbreaks of malaria are expected in areas where the disease has been eradicated but the malaria-carrying mosquitoes (the Anopheles species) are still present.

div.div: How climate change has and will affect our health

source.p: Mounting public concern about the safety of the environment has put scientists under pressure to find out more about how environmental quality affects human health, so that preventive and protective strategies can be put in place.

Unfortunately, however, there is still a lack of detailed information about the interaction between the environment and human health. Because exposure to pollution, chemicals and other contaminants takes place over a whole life-cycle, from the moment of conception through childhood and maturity to old age, data obviously takes a long time to collect. The picture of what is happening to a test subject is also muddied by the reality that there is usually a combination of environmental stressors from different sources. When you add individuals different genetic make-up, age, diet, income and education level to the equation, it can be seen that the situation is extremely complex.

Much of our knowledge is based on experiments in which animals are exposed to lethal levels of chemicals which have acute effects and the information is fed into risk assessment models. But this approach is not capable of reproducing the subtle interactions between the environment and human health. In a formidable challenge for researchers, a new model is being developed that will use toxicology and risk assessment to analyse and assess the interactions realistically. This must be a priority for further research.

Studying animals in the wild is another way of understanding how environmental exposures affect health, as many fundamental physiological processes are similar in animals and humans. The effects on wildlife of persistent organic pollutants (POPs), which come from pesticides and industrial processes, are a good example of this. Marine predators like seals, whales, dolphins and polar bears have been shown to have high levels of POP residues in their bodies, obtained through the food chain, and a number of physiological effects have been observed in them, including infertility, immunodeficiency and different types of tissue malformation.

div.div: Spotting signs of emerging problems in wildlife.

source.h2: What is being done to address the problem
source.p: Although there is limited data confirming definite links between environmental issues and human health, precautionary measures should still be taken, given the uncertainties.

Concern for human health is behind policies that target air, water, soil quality and chemicals, and the EU Environment and Health Action Plan 2004-2010 has identified four top priority groups of diseases and disorders:

ul.li: childhood respiratory disease and asthma
childhood cancer
neurodevelopmental disorders, and
endocrine disruption.

source.p: The European Commissions ambition is to create an integrated environment and health information system, and Children Environment and Health is currently a priority issue on several international agendas. A new proactive and participatory framework for risk analysis and hazard control must be developed which will encompass scientific assessment of risks, uncertainties and ignorance, options for action, communication, and evaluations of actions taken.

But prevention is not only a matter of policy and legislation. Individuals can make a number of lifestyle and behavioural changes to help prevent health problems - eating a balanced diet, taking exercise, and reducing vehicle emissions by cutting down on their use of cars and plane travel, for example.

In a formidable challenge for researchers, a new model is being developed that will use toxicology and risk assessment to analyse and assess the interactions realistically. This must be a priority for further research.

Studying animals in the wild is another way of understanding how environmental exposures affect health, as many fundamental physiological processes are similar in animals and humans. The effects on wildlife of persistent organic pollutants (POPs), which come from pesticides and industrial processes, are a good example of this. Marine predators like seals, whales, dolphins and polar bears have been shown to have high levels of POP residues in their bodies, obtained through the food chain, and a number of physiological effects have been observed in them, including infertility, immunodeficiency and different types of tissue malformation.

div.div: Spotting signs of emerging problems in wildlife.

target.h2: What is being done to address the problem
target.p: Although there is limited data confirming definite links between environmental issues and human health, precautionary measures should still be taken, given the uncertainties.

Concern for human health is behind policies that target air, water, soil quality and chemicals, and the EU Environment and Health Action Plan 2004-2010 has identified four top priority groups of diseases and disorders:

ul.li: childhood respiratory disease and asthma
childhood cancer
neurodevelopmental disorders, and
endocrine disruption.

target.p: The European Commissions ambition is to create an integrated environment and health information system, and Children Environment and Health is currently a priority issue on several international agendas. A new proactive and participatory framework for risk analysis and hazard control must be developed which will encompass scientific assessment of risks, uncertainties and ignorance, options for action, communication, and evaluations of actions taken.

But prevention is not only a matter of policy and legislation. Individuals can make a number of lifestyle and behavioural changes to help prevent health problems - eating a balanced diet, taking exercise, and reducing vehicle emissions by cutting down on their use of cars and plane travel, for example.

source.p: Our economies are based on the use and consumption of natural resources. And it is not just industry - we all consume resources in our homes, through personal travel and our food and drink.

The most environmentally significant resources are materials, energy and land. Some resources, such as forests and fish, are renewable. Others, such as oil and land, are not, and will eventually run out.

blockquote.p: Current materials consumption in industrialised countries is between 31 and 74 tonnes per person per year.
EEA SOER report 2005

p.p: Over the next fifty years the total consumption of natural resources by the world population is projected to be between double and five times what it is now. This continued rise in resource use is likely to have a range of negative effects including materials shortages, ecological crises and possibly even conflict between countries over access to resources.

It is clear that we face an urgent challenge to our production and consumption patterns if we are to manage our resources sustainably and to provide future generations with the materials they need. It is an issue which has been widely debated since the Rio de Janeiro summit in 1992, with many policies put in place since then, such as the 2001 EU Sustainable Development Strategy.

source.h2: Achieving growth while minimising environmental effects
source.p: The ideal we are aiming for is to separate economic growth from damage to the environment. This de-linking is known in environmental policy as decoupling.

Relative decoupling occurs when an environmental problem grows, but more slowly than the underlying economic driver in the same period. Absolute decoupling is when an environmental problem actually decreases while the economy grows.

Over the past decade, there has been a relative decoupling of economic growth from material and energy consumption in many EU countries, i.e. the increase in resource consumption (materials and energy) is no longer in proportion to the rate of economic growth. However, even though Europeans tend to use resources more efficiently, we do not use fewer resources in absolute terms.
source.h2: What drives our material and energy use

blockquote.p: The global population is expected to grow by 50% over the next 50 years.
EEA SOER report 2005

p.p: There are three basic factors which determine how quickly we use up our resources.

First, population size. This is not a significant factor in most European countries, as it is currently static and may even decline in the next 50 years. Nevertheless, the population in the worlds developing countries is rising sharply and this is bound to have an impact on EU use of resources which are consumed or traded globally, such as oil, fish and tropical timber.
Secondly, the extent to which we cover our needs. We have to exchange raw materials in order to produce goods and services which can then be sold on the world market.

blockquote.p: In the 2nd half of the 20th century, global trade volumes grew between 6 to 8 times in size for raw materials, and as much as 40 times for manufactured goods.
EEA SOER report 2005

p.p: The third factor is the patterns of production and consumption, which include the types of technology used and how efficient they are. For instance, introducing fossil energy-based technologies to replace human and animal labour significantly improved production efficiency and increased wealth, but the result was a dramatic increase in the use of natural resources.
Industrialised countries have made significant improvements to their energy and resource efficiency, but some of the gain has been offset by more widespread consumption.

Another pattern of production/consumption is a countrys economic system. Manufacturing and service-oriented economies tend to be fairly stable in their use of basic resources compared with economies based mainly on the extraction and processing of basic natural resources. Most EU Member States have entered the stage of post-industrial growth and have moved towards a service-oriented and knowledge-based economy, so our main driving forces are economic growth and the pattern of development.

Although our economic systems indicate that in general the EUs consumption of resources is not rising as fast as it is elsewhere, the increasing population size and economic growth in developing countries mean that dramatic technological breakthroughs or changes in the patterns of consumption will be needed to achieve a sustainable global balance.

source.p: The Earth is a closed material system, and it is already generally accepted that there are physical limits to continuing economic growth based on increasing resource use. For some non-renewable resources such as fossil fuels and land, availability is already a problem. Fossil fuels will run out, and land is disappearing fast due to increasing urbanisation.
For many renewable resources such as fish stocks, forests and water, the main challenge is to enable them to regenerate sustainably.

Another issue is whether the environment itself can cope with the impacts of resource use. The natural world can only go so far in acting as a sink to absorb discharges and emissions without being seriously affected. For example, we are currently seeing signs that a possibly irreversible climate change is taking place as a result of emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases.

Renewable resources are ones that can regenerate in a relatively short time. If their use is to be sustainable, their consumption or extraction rate needs to be maintained within the reproductive capacity of the natural system in question.

blockquote.p: Annual average run-off from rainfall varies from more than 3,000 mm in western Norway to less than 25 mm in southern and central Spain.
EEA SOER report 2005

p.p: In general, Europe does not suffer from the devastating water shortages and poor water quality experienced by some other parts of the world, although several countries have been experiencing local water shortages. Yet water is under threat in many parts of Europe because of rising population in urban areas, economic growth, intensive agriculture, growing tourism and leisure activities, and from the lack of proper supply and treatment facilities. It is a problem both of quantity and quality.

Chemicals and waste have historically been the main pollutants of water, but over the past twenty years considerable progress has been made in reducing industrial and urban discharges, and contamination of drinking and bathing water is now largely under control.
There has been far less success in controlling discharges from agriculture, however, and high concentrations of pesticides and heavy metals can still be found in many European waters.

source.p: The seas around Europe provide about 10% of the worlds fish catches, but many of our stocks are now considered to be in a critical state. Despite policies to reduce catches, most fish stocks in European waters are over-fished or fully exploited, threatening fish populations and provoking conflicts between EU Member States.

Cod is a good example of a marine fish resource under pressure. Over-fishing in the North Sea for decades has resulted in a small and young spawning stock, and yet the optimal catch age is 6-7 years when the fish weigh around 8 kilos. If spawning stocks were allowed to grow, the annual value of the yield could double from around EUR 200 to 400 million.

There are obvious long-term gains from the sustainable use and management of fish. Larger yields can be created, local fishing communities can continue to develop, and there is less risk of long-term adverse effects on marine ecosystems.

div.div: Historical lessons from sustainable resource examples

blockquote.p: The term sustainable was first used in 1713 by Hans Carl von Carlowitz to refer to the ability to replace what is cut down from a forest.

p.p: Forests provide benefits to our ecology and our economy. Forest area accounts for around a third of Europes territory, and is increasing on average by about half a million hectares a year. Tree conditions and soil quality have improved to a certain extent because of the decrease in atmospheric pollution from industrial emissions of sulphur dioxide and nitrogen oxide. There has been a steady increase in the consumption of all forest products.
The continuing acidification of soils and climate change are the issues that need to be dealt with if there is to be sustainable management of our expanding forests.

source.p: Non-renewable resources are ones whose natural regeneration cycle is extremely long. For example, fossil fuels and soils do regenerate but this takes thousands of years.

The use of resources needs be managed in such a way that future generations should have enough for their needs and be able to live in a world that is not environmentally degraded as a result of our over-consumption.

There are various ways of reducing the use and impacts and consumption of non-renewable resources. One option is to use them more efficiently, as with more fuel-efficient cars. Another possibility is to extend their life-cycle by maintenance, reuse and recycling.
For some resources such as fossil fuels and land, scarcity is a real threat.

Most of the energy we use in Europe comes from fossil fuels. Each year almost 4 tonnes are consumed per capita in the 15 original member countries of the EU and about half that is imported. Energy consumption is increasing, mainly because of growth in transport but also in the household and service sectors. On a more positive note, fossil fuel-related emissions of air pollutants have come down over the last ten years, thanks to the use of end-of-pipe cleaning equipment such as catalytic convertors.

Whether we will have enough fossil fuels for our needs in the years to come is a matter of debate. Global reserves are finite and the question is not whether but when the reserves will be exhausted. Some estimates show that the mid-depletion point of worldwide crude oil reserves could be reached within the next 10-20 years.

blockquote.p: About 47% of European land is used for agriculture, 36% for forestry, and 17% for all other uses, including cities, towns and infrastructure.
EEA SOER report 2005

p.p: Although land cannot be consumed as such, it is under threat from human activities through:

ul.li: Sealing (isolation of the soil from the atmosphere by a covering such as asphalt pavements)
Deforestation or agricultural activities which leach nutrients or erode the soil
Contamination from mines, industry and landfills, among other sources.

source.p: It can take centuries for soil to recover naturally from all these activities - the rate of soil generation in Europe can be as low as 5 cm in 500 years.

All major European cities and urban areas have high proportions of sealed land. During the last twenty years built-up areas have expanded in Europe by 20%, in contrast to the population size which has only increased by 6%.
Road building, as well as leading to the negative effects of sealing, is the main contributor to the increasing fragmentation of the landscape.

blockquote.p: In 2000 Germanys increase in urban areas and infrastructure was about 50,000 hectares, with a total area equivalent to eighty football pitches being sealed every day.
EEA SOER Report 2005

p.p: Agricultures continuing search for efficiency, lower costs and increased scale of production is putting substantial pressure on the environment, landscapes and biodiversity. An example of its impact is the fact that more land has been converted to cropland since 1945 than in the 18th and 19th centuries put together.

source.p: The use and management of natural resources are directly or indirectly addressed in almost all the EU policies (the Common Agricultural Policy, the Common Fisheries Policies, regional development policy, and transport and energy policies) whether environmentally-oriented or not.
On the whole, these policies have resulted in better management of impacts on the environment, but there are considerable differences between countries, and many have great potential for improvement.

Europe needs to prepare for the effects of a global increase in resource consumption. It is unlikely that simply by making technological improvements we can significantly reduce our use of resources and we may have to adopt a radically different approach towards the sustainability of our current lifestyles and patterns of consumption.

'Don’t divorce the river from its basin.'
H. B. N. Hynes (1970)

'Don’t divorce the river from its basin.'
H. B. N. Hynes (1970)

p.i: This is the basic principle of the Water Framework Directive. Water quality, biological conditions and the amount of water flowing in a river ultimately depend on what happens in the river basin.

source.p: Under natural conditions rivers would all have good status, but unfortunately human activities in the basin over thousands of years have considerably altered many of our rivers.

p.b: Overview

source.p: The WISE public viewer picks up this focus and presents environmental data at European level as part of the nationally designated river basin district ('My river basin district').
Information and data are currently available on:

ul.li: river basin district and their management bodies;
water quality, as measured by the European state of the environment reporting;
bathing water quality for all designated European beaches – both coastal and inland;
initial data on the treatment of urban waste water in the EU-15 Member States.

source.p: This current snapshot should be seen as a starting point for informing and taking measures on the environmental conditions in the area.

The Water Framework Directive (WFD) utilises the river basin as the natural unit for water management. Each river basin within a Member State must be assigned to a river basin district (RBD). Member States are responsible for coordination of administrative arrangements for water management in relation to each RBD within its territory.

p.b: What is a river basin district ?

source.p: A river basin district is an area of land from which all surface run-off flows through a sequence of streams, rivers and possibly lakes into the sea at a single river mouth, estuary or delta. It also constitutes an area of land and sea made up of one or more neighbouring river basins together with their associated groundwater and coastal waters — if applicable. Moreover, it is identified as the main area for coordinated water management. In addition, coastal waters shall be identified and assigned to the nearest or most appropriate river basin district up to one nautical mile beyond the baseline from which the Member State's territorial waters are measured. Local authorities (competent authorities) will have the primary role in promoting, establishing and implementing these projects.

trans-unit.source: One of the EEA’s key activities in the field of energy is monitoring the integration of environmental considerations in the energy sector. A set of ‘energy and environment indicators’ is updated and published annually. Building on this, the EEA publishes an energy and environment report on a regular basis, as well as assessments of the expected environmental benefits and pressures from different shares of renewable energy.
trans-unit.target: One of the EEA’s key activities in the field of energy is monitoring the integration of environmental considerations in the energy sector. A set of ‘energy and environment indicators’ is updated and published annually. Building on this, the EEA publishes an energy and environment report on a regular basis, as well as assessments of the expected environmental benefits and pressures from different shares of renewable energy.

source.p: The energy–environment indicators are organised around six policy questions:

ul.li: Is the use and production of energy having a decreasing impact on the environment?
Is energy use decreasing?
How rapidly is energy efficiency increasing?
Is there a switch to less polluting fuels?
How rapidly are renewable energy technologies being implemented?
Are environmental costs being better incorporated into the pricing system?

source.p: The indicators are also important for monitoring the EU Sustainable Development Strategy, preparing the EU greenhouse gas inventory report to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (UNFCCC), and reporting on the greenhouse gas emission trends and projections in Europe under the Kyoto Protocol.

The EEA’s energy and environment report analyses these relevant issues in an integrated way — addressing energy production and consumption, renewable energy sources, new technologies, energy efficiency, greenhouse gas emissions and climate change. The report builds on the set of energy and environment indicators.

The EEA also carries out assessments of the environmental benefits and pressures that are expected to arise from different shares of renewable energy as a proportion of total energy production, in 2010, 2020 and 2030. This includes:

ul.li: analysis of the environmental benefits and impacts from different uses of biomass for transport, heat and electricity;
identification of the wind energy potential that is available in Europe without creating additional pressures on the environment.

trans-unit.source: Understanding household consumption patterns is about understanding human behaviour. Consumption patterns in Europe are very different to those 50 years ago. Important factors that drive our consumption include growing incomes, globalisation of the economy, technological breakthroughs (such as the Internet and mobile phones), decreasing household sizes and an ageing population. At the same time, the growing number of goods and services we consume often offsets the efficiency gains we achieved through for example, improved production technologies and processes. As a result, environmental pressures are increasing. Housing, food and drink, and mobility have the greatest environmental impact over their lifecycle in terms of emissions of greenhouse gases, acidifying and ozone-depleting substances as well as resource use.

At the same time, the growing number of goods and services we consume often offsets the efficiency gains we achieved through for example, improved production technologies and processes. As a result, environmental pressures are increasing. Housing, food and drink, and mobility have the greatest environmental impact over their lifecycle in terms of emissions of greenhouse gases, acidifying and ozone-depleting substances as well as resource use.

source.p: In Western and Central Europe (EU-27 plus Norway, Liechtenstein, and Switzerland), between 1990 and 2005, consumption expenditure increased by 25 %. Households spend between three and five times more than the public sector. The negative environmental effects of our consumption do not occur only across Europe, but also in other regions of the world. This is mainly a result of resource extraction, production, processing and transportation of the goods we consume in Europe. Tourism is yet another way of exporting our environmental impacts.

Our eating and drinking habits lead to significant environmental pressures. We cause these directly by travelling to the shops, storing, cooking and generating waste. Indirectly, and even more importantly, there exist also the effects linked to food production, processing and transportation.

We buy increasing numbers of electronic goods like TVs, DVDs, PCs, laptops, mobile phones, stereos and kitchen appliances, and we also replace these more frequently. Households account for 28.8 % of electricity used in Europe, and consumption of electricity by the households is on the rise. We also build larger homes for fewer people whilst using more energy in our homes. Space-heating is still by far the largest household energy end-use in the EU (70 %).  Every European citizen on average throws away 520 kg of household waste per year, and this figure is projected to grow further.

Car travel and aviation continue to grow, leading to increasing energy consumption and emission of greenhouse gases. Increased car traffic is a major cause of air pollution and also causes noise problems in cities. Today's trend towards living in new, low-density urban areas is resulting in urban sprawl causing increased consumption of energy, resources, transport and land.

Tourism is one of the fastest growing sectors. Travel to and from the destination is most often done by car or plane. In tourist destinations, the consumption of water and energy, the use of land and the generation of waste and wastewater are all increasing.

target.p: In Western and Central Europe (EU-27 plus Norway, Liechtenstein, and Switzerland), between 1990 and 2005, consumption expenditure increased by 25 %. Households spend between three and five times more than the public sector. The negative environmental effects of our consumption do not occur only across Europe, but also in other regions of the world. This is mainly a result of resource extraction, production, processing and transportation of the goods we consume in Europe. Tourism is yet another way of exporting our environmental impacts.

Our eating and drinking habits lead to significant environmental pressures. We cause these directly by travelling to the shops, storing, cooking and generating waste. Indirectly, and even more importantly, there exist also the effects linked to food production, processing and transportation.

We buy increasing numbers of electronic goods like TVs, DVDs, PCs, laptops, mobile phones, stereos and kitchen appliances, and we also replace these more frequently. div.div: Red light
copyright Flo Holzinger

div.p: An efficient and flexible transport system is essential for our economy and our quality of life. The current European system poses significant and in some cases growing threats to the environment, to human health, and to the economy.

Transport is mostly a means to an end, but transport users are locked into production and consumption patterns that are not easily changed in the short term, i.e. companies are located in certain places and need supplies, people need to go to work, children need to go to school etc.

The transport supply and demand patterns that Europe experiences today are the results of decades of planned and unplanned developments. Changing these patterns in a more sustainable direction requires coherent policies implemented over a long time.

Databases
The core data of the LEAC project have been structured in a relational database model in order to allow quick and easy analyses. These databases have been made publicly accessible through the Internet.

Layers
From the LEAC database, various geographical layers have been derived such as land cover flows, Corilis, the green potential background layer and the dominant land-cover types.

trans-unit.source: Sustainable household consumption is not yet backed by well-defined policy objectives and measures. Changing people's behaviour is difficult and often politically sensitive. Some policy instruments, such as eco-labelling, environmental taxes or subsidies, raising awareness, and product standards, are already used to change consumption patterns in a more sustainable direction. Increasingly, the focus is on the sustainable consumption and production policies. This is a common challenge where all players, including public authorities, business and consumers, come together to take responsibility and implement actions. Solutions are being looked for at the global level: in Europe and other world regions, as well as nationally and locally.
trans-unit.target: Sustainable household consumption is not yet backed by well-defined policy objectives and measures. Changing people's behaviour is difficult and often politically sensitive. Some policy instruments, such as eco-labelling, environmental taxes or subsidies, raising awareness, and product standards, are already used to change consumption patterns in a more sustainable direction. Increasingly, the focus is on the sustainable consumption and production policies. This is a common challenge where all players, including public authorities, business and consumers, come together to take responsibility and implement actions. Solutions are being looked for at the global level: in Europe and other world regions, as well as nationally and locally.

source.p: The role of public authorities is to provide the framework within which business and consumers can operate — using legal, market-based information and other tools. Businesses face the challenge of producing goods and services that are sustainable over their entire life-cycle. The challenge for consumers is to choose sustainable goods and services — as far as these are known, available or affordable.

Sustainable consumption makes part of the Agenda 21, which was adopted at the Nations Conference on Environment and Development (UNCED) held in Rio de Janeiro in 1992. At the 2002 World Summit on Sustainable Development in Johannesburg, an agreement was reached to develop a framework of programmes on sustainable consumption and production (SCP) and in 2003, the global 'Marrakech Process' was started to develop this framework. In 2010 and 2011, the United Nations Commission on Sustainable Development will review this global process to achieve more sustainable consumption and production.

In order to raise awareness, as well as to influence consumer behaviour and improve the environmental performance of products and services, there are several policy instruments in current use.  Examples include the eco-labelling of food products, such as organic foods, and the energy-efficiency labelling of household appliances. Energy consumption is also tackled by other EU policies, e.g. the EU Action Plan for Energy Efficiency, the strategy to reduce CO2 emissions from new cars and vans, and the Energy Performance of Buildings Directive.

Sustainable consumption and production is now one of the seven key challenges of the renewed EU Sustainable Development Strategy. The European Commission is expected to issue a Sustainable Consumption and Production (SCP) Action plan in 2008.

A number of EEA member countries have adopted sustainable consumption and production action plans of their own or address those issues as part of their sustainable development strategies. Other countries are dealing with these challenges using other names or headings. Sometimes consumption issues are tackled via sectoral policies such as environment, transport, energy or agricultural policies. Many initiatives and actions are also taken at the regional and local level, for example within regional sustainable development strategies and the Agenda 21 processes.

ul.li: Environment Directorate-General of the European Commission

trans-unit.source: Transport - getting from A to B
trans-unit.target: Transport - getting from A to B

div.div: Night Traffic
EEA

div.p: We now use transport far more than we did twenty or thirty years ago. We travel further to get to our places of work and the shops, we make many more plane trips, and we consume goods and produce that have been carried from the other side of the world.

Our habits and patterns of consumption have been formed over many years and are the result of the opening up of international markets, rapid economic growth, and town planning which did not have minimisation of transport as a priority.
Yet these transport habits come at a price: harm to our health and the environment.

Although the emissions from vehicle exhausts have decreased because we now have cleaner fuel and more efficient engines, the air in our cities is still polluted because motorised vehicles are being used much more often, and over longer distances, than they were in the past.

Carbon dioxide emissions  thought to be the main contributor to climate change  have also been growing steadily because our transport use is growing faster than the energy efficiency of our vehicles.
There is no easy solution to these environmental problems. Much is already being done, but there is still a long way to go.

ul.li: Between 1990 and 2002, passenger travel increased in most European countries by 30%, and road and air travel have grown faster than other modes of transport.
Freight transport has also risen steeply, by 34% over the past decade.
Marine transport is responsible for a very large share of freight transport (three quarters of the total EU freight transport figure).
In the UK, Netherlands and Denmark, passenger cars are driven with an average of only 1.6 persons per car.
Train occupancies are generally low. In most European countries, less than 30% of the seats are generally occupied. Aircraft occupancy rates are much higher at around 60%.

source.h2: How does transport affect the environment?

ul.li: Petroleum-powered engines produce carbon dioxide (thought to be the main cause of climate change), nitrous oxides and fine particles which pollute the air, and sulphur oxides which contribute to acid rain.
Emission of air pollutants has been reduced in Europe by about a third over the past decade but evidence indicates that as many as 370,000 people die prematurely each year due to air pollution.
Greenhouse gas emissions from transport have increased by around 23% since 1990.
Maritime transport is responsible for 13% of the world's total transport greenhouse gas emissions.

Roads, railways and airports cut the land into small pieces, putting natural habitats at risk, so that many species die out. Wildlife and plants are also threatened by the accompanying air pollution, noise and light disturbances.
In the 1990s, about 10 hectares a day were taken for motorway construction alone.
New emissions technologies are already being developed and marketed.
EU standards on emissions from vehicles may be made tighter.
Standards on aircraft emissions could be applied to cruising at altitude, and a fuel tax could be introduced for intra-EU flights.
Biofuels will be improved and used more widely. (At present, biofuels make up less than 1% of total road transport fuel consumption.)
A higher proportion of transport use could be shifted from road to rail.
Better town planning could help to ensure that homes are closer to shops and places of work.
Charging could be applied to reflect the true environmental cost. (In Sweden, the environmental performance of ships determines the price for the use of certain sea routes.)
Vehicle taxes could be aligned to environmental performance.
Car-sharing lanes could be introduced more widely.

City bicycle lanes and networks could be improved. (A project in Odense, Denmark, developed 50 pro-cycling initiatives, including physical improvements of bicycle infrastructure, changes in regulations and awareness campaigns. During the project period, the citizens of Odense made about 25,000 new cycle journeys per day, half of which were previously made by car.)

Public transport could be improved. (Thirty years ago, the city of Curitiba in Brazil constructed a low-cost alternative to a metro system involving bus lanes, elevated covered platforms for loading and unloading and short intervals between buses. Now around 70% of commuters use the bus system every day.)

trans-unit.source: For policy-makers and individuals alike, it is important to know which consumption and production areas have the highest impact on the environment, as well as which policies and choices can really make a difference. The work of EEA focuses on the development of indicators and assessment of environmental impacts together with policy analysis. Our work aims at supporting the European Commission, Parliament and Council, the United Nations, national governments and other stakeholders in finding the most effective paths to sustainable consumption.

The work of EEA focuses on the development of indicators and assessment of environmental impacts together with policy analysis. Our work aims at supporting the European Commission, Parliament and Council, the United Nations, national governments and other stakeholders in finding the most effective paths to sustainable consumption.

ul.li: Several indicators are already available showing which trends in consumption contribute to the environmental impacts of consumption;
Work is in process to develop a framework and indicators for sustainable consumption (and production) in Europe.

h2.strong: Impacts of consumption (and production) in Europe

ul.li: Analyses of  the environmental pressures from consumption (and production);

Assessment of the environmental impacts of household consumption, either in dedicated reports or as part of the 'state of the environment' reports, e.g. the  Europe's environment — The fourth assessment (2007);

Support to non-EU regions in finding possible pathways to sustainable consumption (and production), e.g. analysis of the situation in South-East Europe and Eastern Europe, as well as in the Caucasus and Central Asia in a joint UNEP/EEA report (2007).
Organisation of conferences and workshops, e.g. the conference 'Time for action: towards sustainable consumption and production in Europe' in September 2007;
Collection of information and analysis of national policies of the EEA member countries, e.g. in the report 'Time for action — towards sustainable consumption and production in Europe'.

source.p: The Group for Sustainable Consumption and Production leads the Agency's work in this field, and is supported by the European Topic Centre on Resource and Waste Management (ETC/RWM) (Internet: http://waste.eionet.europa.eu/). Specific aspects of household consumption are also covered by EEA activities in other areas, e.g. climate change and energy, transport and agriculture.
