div.div: Night Traffic
EEA

div.p: We need fast, flexible transport for our economies to flourish and to maintain our high standard of living. Yet our ever-increasing demand for mobility pollutes the air and adds to the volume of greenhouse gases (GHGs) which are thought to be the main cause of climate change.

Roads and railways cut natural and agricultural areas into ever smaller pieces, threatening the existence of our wildlife and plants. High levels of traffic noise affect human health. And more than a hundred people die on the EUs roads every day. Much has already been done to address the transport dilemma, but there is no simple solution. Fuel and vehicles have both become cleaner over the past decade, but because means of transport are being used more often and over longer distances than in the past, the overall situation as regards air pollution is only improving slowly and, in the case of GHG emissions from transport, is actually getting worse.

source.p: Transport users are locked into consumption patterns that are not easily changed in the short term and which are the result of decades of planned and unplanned developments.

blockquote.p: Between 1990 and 2002, the average passenger travel distance increased in European countries by 30%, and road and air travel have grown faster than other modes of transport. The motorway and high speed rail networks have increased rapidly, while the conventional rail and inland waterways infrastructures have slowly shrunk.
Transport and environment: TERM 2005, EEA report

source.p: Traditionally, transport growth parallels economic growth. Research shows that people are willing to spend a fixed share of their income and time on transport, so the increase in travel is directly linked to the fact that earnings have risen. Private cars are expensive to buy but generally cheaper to run than taking public transport, and the higher speeds of most forms of transport mean that we can travel further in less time.

The increase in air travel is due partly to the rise of low-cost air travel in Europe, where a plane ticket can cost as little as a visit to the theatre. Badly thought out urban planning is another reason for the rise in travel kilometres.

Over the last century, cars and roads have played a leading role in transforming society. Shopping has, to a large extent, moved to supermarkets and shopping malls, and workers have relocated to live further from their place of employment. The result has been an increasing reliance on transport for many daily tasks.

The shift of basic services from residential areas to the outskirts of major cities, coupled with the decline in public transport, has led to a reduction in neighbourhood quality of life. People who have no car are disadvantaged by being less mobile and having fewer choices about where to live and work.

Freight transport has also risen steeply, by 34% over the past decade. More goods are carried over longer distances and more frequently than ever before. Again, this is partly a result of growing incomes which enable people to consume more, which in turn increases transport demand.

The distances between consumers and producers have grown, facilitated by the removal of barriers to trade in the internal market and globally. A familiar example of this is supermarkets being able to offer fresh produce from all corners of the world.In manufacturing, components are made and assembled in more than one location, because low transport costs allow companies to benefit from lower labour costs and particular skills in different regions. Lorries and vans are generally faster, cheaper, more reliable and more flexible than rail and inland waterway transport, so smaller but more frequent loads can be delivered exactly when needed. This tendency to 'just in time' deliveries has been reinforced by the high property prices in city centres which make it expensive to store large quantities of goods.
Marine transport is responsible for a very large share of freight transport - three quarters of the total EU freight transport figure.

blockquote.p: Sea transport for the EU-15 (2003) amounts to nearly 7 trillion tonne-km. This figure dwarfs the 1.7 trillion tonne-km performance of road, rail and inland waterways combined.
Transport and environment: TERM 2005, EEA report

source.p: These figures have particular significance, as shipping obviously takes place mainly on the high seas where emission regulations are less stringent.
source.h2: The impact on health and climate
source.p: Motorised transport is one of the most important sources of harmful emissions, and the biggest consumer of oil. The combustion of fossil fuels in engines produces, amongst others:

ul.li: carbon dioxide, the GHG considered to be the main cause of climate change
nitrous oxides and particulate matter, which pollute the air
sulphur oxides, which contribute to acid rain that damages buildings and contaminates lakes, rivers, crops and trees
ground level ozone, which causes respiratory problems.

source.p: Emission of air pollutants has been significantly reduced in Europe over the past decade - by around a third. Yet in spite of this, we are still faced with air quality problems. The air quality limits which have been set for particulate matter have not been met in many cities, and ozone incidents are frequent.

blockquote.p: There is growing evidence to show that the effect that fine particles have on health has been underestimated, and that as many as 370,000 people die prematurely each year due to air pollution from particulate matter, nitrous oxides and ozone.
Transport and environment: TERM 2005, EEA report

source.p: As regards GHGs, all EU Member States have committed themselves to reducing emissions in accordance with the Kyoto Protocol. In the case of industry they have been substantially reduced, but GHG emissions from transport have increased by around 23% since 1990. So the reduction in emissions from industry has to a large extent been offset, making it more difficult for countries to meet the Kyoto targets.

Developed countries will need to reduce emissions by up to 80% by 2050 if we are to maintain a global temperature below the 2°C increase threshold set by EU ministers. So if transport emissions do not reduce from todays level (around 20%) they would consume our total quota by 2050. Acidifying emissions from transport have decreased by 34% since 2003, mainly due to innovations in exhaust gas treatment in road vehicles and improvements in fuel quality.
Transport infrastructure puts pressure on natural habitats and biodiversity through the direct use of land, disturbances from noise and light, air pollution and the breaking up of landscapes.

It is in the most highly populated areas that land is cut into the smallest fragments by airports, road and rail networks, and is therefore greatest in western and central Europe. The landscape here has been extremely fragmented for a long time and many species disappeared long ago. In the remote and less fragmented areas such as Arctic Europe, fragmentation is growing because of the increase in transport construction, and this is having a serious impact on biodiversity.

blockquote.p: Roads consume approximately 90% of the total area of land used for transport in Europe. In the 1990s, about 10 hectares a day were taken for motorway construction alone.
Transport and environment: TERM 2005, EEA report

source.p: As transport infrastructure expands, more and more designated nature areas will come under pressure. About half in Europe are already affected.

The world's energy needs are predicted to be almost 60% higher in 2030 than today. Transport relies on oil for more than 98% of its energy consumption, and is therefore very vulnerable to the shrinking of supplies.

Experts disagree on the exact timing of the worlds oil production peak, but agree that it is most likely to happen within the next 25 years. When it does happen, a number of alternative options to energy saving and renewable energy (such as producing synthetic fuels from natural gas, coal or oil-sand) will become more economically viable than they currently are. However, the life-cycle emissions of GHGs of these alternatives are generally higher than conventional fuels, and so will represent an additional burden on the environment.

div.div: More information on the sustainability of fossil fuels.

source.p: There is no single solution to the problem of transports various impacts on the environment. In the short term, measures like improvements of logistics and better use of more efficient vehicles can reduce transport usage considerably. But in the long run consumption patterns will also have to be addressed.

Shifting a higher proportion of transport use from road to rail is seen as a good thing, because trains are generally more environmentally friendly than lorries and cars. However, specific measures such as building new rail infrastructure may in some cases boost rail transport without decreasing transport by road because the new infrastructure does not meet the needs of present road transport users.

Better vehicle technology is another way forward. The new emission abatement technologies (such as particle filters, exhaust gas recirculation and selective catalytic reduction) have the potential to reduce radically the emissions of nitrous oxides and particles in road and rail transport, and inland and sea shipping.

div.div: Find out more about new vehicle technologies

source.p: Aligning the environmental performance of vehicles to charges and taxes is one option that is being discussed and in some cases implemented. In Sweden, for example, the environmental performance of ships determines the price for the use of certain sea routes. However, charges can have unwelcome side effects.

Many motorways in the EU are tolled for financing reasons but with little or no reflection of environmental performance in the charge structure. If these are included in the charge, and charging schemes are not extended to all roads, traffic could just be diverted away from main roads to minor ones.

div.div: More information on distance related charges

source.p: One way to reduce GHG emissions is by using lower net carbon fuels such as biofuels, one of the few alternatives to petrol and diesel. These are made from biomass, which absorbs carbon while growing, so biofuels represent a lower carbon route to transport fuels. Unfortunately, however, harmful substances can be emitted during the tilling, harvesting and fertilising of the biomass.
Biofuels also require large areas of land for production and compete with other land uses (such as extensive farming or forestation) and other uses of biomass, such as fuel for heat and power plants.

blockquote.p: At present, biofuels make up less than 1% of total road transport fuel consumption, while petrol and diesel cover 98%. (The remaining 1% is mostly covered by gas).
Transport and environment: TERM 2005, EEA report

div.div: More information on biofuels

source.p: Moving towards a more sustainable transport system will require an integrated approach by policy-makers. Problems will need to be considered well in advance and not just tackled at the end-of-pipe phase via regulations relating to emissions.

Long-term measures will be required across many areas of policy and, if they are to be successful, must take into account not only the direct environmental impact but also what the impact will be on transport demand.

div.div: Night Traffic
EEA

div.p: We need fast, flexible transport for our economies to flourish and to maintain our high standard of living. Yet our ever-increasing demand for mobility pollutes the air and adds to the volume of greenhouse gases (GHGs) which are thought to be the main cause of climate change.

Roads and railways cut natural and agricultural areas into ever smaller pieces, threatening the existence of our wildlife and plants. High levels of traffic noise affect human health. And more than a hundred people die on the EUs roads every day. Much has already been done to address the transport dilemma, but there is no simple solution. Fuel and vehicles have both become cleaner over the past decade, but because means of transport are being used more often and over longer distances than in the past, the overall situation as regards air pollution is only improving slowly and, in the case of GHG emissions from transport, is actually getting worse.

target.p: Transport users are locked into consumption patterns that are not easily changed in the short term and which are the result of decades of planned and unplanned developments.

blockquote.p: Between 1990 and 2002, the average passenger travel distance increased in European countries by 30%, and road and air travel have grown faster than other modes of transport. The motorway and high speed rail networks have increased rapidly, while the conventional rail and inland waterways infrastructures have slowly shrunk.
Transport and environment: TERM 2005, EEA report

target.p: Traditionally, transport growth parallels economic growth. Research shows that people are willing to spend a fixed share of their income and time on transport, so the increase in travel is directly linked to the fact that earnings have risen. Private cars are expensive to buy but generally cheaper to run than taking public transport, and the higher speeds of most forms of transport mean that we can travel further in less time.

The increase in air travel is due partly to the rise of low-cost air travel in Europe, where a plane ticket can cost as little as a visit to the theatre. Badly thought out urban planning is another reason for the rise in travel kilometres.

Over the last century, cars and roads have played a leading role in transforming society. Shopping has, to a large extent, moved to supermarkets and shopping malls, and workers have relocated to live further from their place of employment. The result has been an increasing reliance on transport for many daily tasks.

The shift of basic services from residential areas to the outskirts of major cities, coupled with the decline in public transport, has led to a reduction in neighbourhood quality of life. People who have no car are disadvantaged by being less mobile and having fewer choices about where to live and work.

Freight transport has also risen steeply, by 34% over the past decade. More goods are carried over longer distances and more frequently than ever before. Again, this is partly a result of growing incomes which enable people to consume more, which in turn increases transport demand.

The distances between consumers and producers have grown, facilitated by the removal of barriers to trade in the internal market and globally. A familiar example of this is supermarkets being able to offer fresh produce from all corners of the world.In manufacturing, components are made and assembled in more than one location, because low transport costs allow companies to benefit from lower labour costs and particular skills in different regions. Lorries and vans are generally faster, cheaper, more reliable and more flexible than rail and inland waterway transport, so smaller but more frequent loads can be delivered exactly when needed. This tendency to 'just in time' deliveries has been reinforced by the high property prices in city centres which make it expensive to store large quantities of goods.
Marine transport is responsible for a very large share of freight transport - three quarters of the total EU freight transport figure.

blockquote.p: Sea transport for the EU-15 (2003) amounts to nearly 7 trillion tonne-km. This figure dwarfs the 1.7 trillion tonne-km performance of road, rail and inland waterways combined.
Transport and environment: TERM 2005, EEA report

target.p: These figures have particular significance, as shipping obviously takes place mainly on the high seas where emission regulations are less stringent.
target.h2: The impact on health and climate
target.p: Motorised transport is one of the most important sources of harmful emissions, and the biggest consumer of oil. The combustion of fossil fuels in engines produces, amongst others:

ul.li: carbon dioxide, the GHG considered to be the main cause of climate change
nitrous oxides and particulate matter, which pollute the air
sulphur oxides, which contribute to acid rain that damages buildings and contaminates lakes, rivers, crops and trees
ground level ozone, which causes respiratory problems.

target.p: Emission of air pollutants has been significantly reduced in Europe over the past decade - by around a third. Yet in spite of this, we are still faced with air quality problems. The air quality limits which have been set for particulate matter have not been met in many cities, and ozone incidents are frequent.

blockquote.p: There is growing evidence to show that the effect that fine particles have on health has been underestimated, and that as many as 370,000 people die prematurely each year due to air pollution from particulate matter, nitrous oxides and ozone.

target.p: As regards GHGs, all EU Member States have committed themselves to reducing emissions in accordance with the Kyoto Protocol. In the case of industry they have been substantially reduced, but GHG emissions from transport have increased by around 23% since 1990. So the reduction in emissions from industry has to a large extent been offset, making it more difficult for countries to meet the Kyoto targets.

Developed countries will need to reduce emissions by up to 80% by 2050 if we are to maintain a global temperature below the 2°C increase threshold set by EU ministers. So if transport emissions do not reduce from todays level (around 20%) they would consume our total quota by 2050. Acidifying emissions from transport have decreased by 34% since 2003, mainly due to innovations in exhaust gas treatment in road vehicles and improvements in fuel quality.

trans-unit.source: A clean environment is essential for human health and well-being. However, the interactions between the environment and human health are highly complex and difficult to assess. This makes the use of the precautionary principle particularly useful. The best-known health impacts are related to ambient air pollution, poor water quality and insufficient sanitation. Much less is known about the health impacts of hazardous chemicals. Noise is an emerging environment and health issue. Climate change, depletion of stratospheric ozone, loss of biodiversity, and land degradation can also affect human health.
trans-unit.target: A clean environment is essential for human health and well-being. However, the interactions between the environment and human health are highly complex and difficult to assess. This makes the use of the precautionary principle particularly useful. The best-known health impacts are related to ambient air pollution, poor water quality and insufficient sanitation. Much less is known about the health impacts of hazardous chemicals. Noise is an emerging environment and health issue. Climate change, depletion of stratospheric ozone, loss of biodiversity, and land degradation can also affect human health.

source.p: In Europe, the major environment-related health concerns are related to outdoor and indoor air pollution, poor water quality, poor sanitation and hazardous chemicals. The related health impacts include respiratory and cardiovascular diseases, cancer, asthma and allergies, as well as reproductive and neurodevelopmental disorders.

Fine particulate matter and ground-level ozone are the main threats to human health from air pollution. The EU's Clean Air for Europe (CAFE) programme estimated a total of 348 000 premature deaths per year due to exposure to fine particles (PM2.5). At this level of exposure, average life expectancy is reduced by approximately one year.

The EU Green Paper on noise exposure states that around 20 % of the EU’s population suffer from noise levels that health experts consider to be unacceptable, i.e. which can lead to annoyance, sleep disturbance and adverse health effects.
Transport, especially in urban areas, is one of the key contributors to human exposure to air pollution and noise.

Much less is known about the health impacts of chemicals. There is growing concern about the effects of exposure to mixtures of chemicals at low levels and for long periods over our life-time, in particular during early childhood and pregnancy.

Persistent chemicals with long-term effects, such as polychlorinated biphenyls (PCBs) and chlorofluorocarbons CFCs, and those used in long-life structures — for example construction materials — may present risks even after their production has been phased out.

Many pollutants known to affect human health are gradually coming under regulatory control. However, there are emerging issues for which environmental pathways and effects on health are as yet poorly understood. Examples are electromagnetic fields (EMF), pharmaceuticals in the environment and some infectious diseases (the spreading of which may be affected by climate change). The development of ‘early warning’ systems should be encouraged to shorten the time between detection of a potential hazard and a policy action or intervention.

Human health has always been threatened by natural hazards such as storms, floods, fires, landslides and droughts. Their consequences are being worsened by a lack of preparedness and by human actions such as deforestation, climate change and biodiversity loss.

trans-unit.source: The European economy is based on a high level of resource consumption. This includes raw materials (such as metals, construction minerals or wood), energy and land. The main driving forces of Europe's resource consumption are economic growth, technological developments and changing consumption and production patterns. About one third of resources used are turned into waste and emissions. Around four tonnes of waste per capita are generated every year in the EEA member countries. Every European citizen on average throws away 520 kg of household waste per year, and this figure is expected to increase.
trans-unit.target: The European economy is based on a high level of resource consumption. This includes raw materials (such as metals, construction minerals or wood), energy and land. The main driving forces of Europe's resource consumption are economic growth, technological developments and changing consumption and production patterns. About one third of resources used are turned into waste and emissions. Around four tonnes of waste per capita are generated every year in the EEA member countries. Every European citizen on average throws away 520 kg of household waste per year, and this figure is expected to increase.

source.p: In the EU-15, use of materials has changed little over the past two decades, and remains at about 15–16 tonnes per capita per year. However, this number varies considerably from country to country, from some 12 tonnes per capita in Italy to 38 tonnes per capita in Finland. Construction materials have the largest share in this, followed by fossil fuels and biomass. Efficiency of resource use is several times higher in the EU-15 than in the new EU Member States or the countries of South-eastern Europe. Projections to 2020 indicate that resource use in the EU will continue to increase.

Resource use is also increasing in other regions of the world. This is partly due to increased consumption of goods and services in Europe, often based on resources extracted from these other regions.

div.p: The EU aims to 'improve resource efficiency to reduce the overall use of non-renewable natural resources and the related environmental impacts of raw materials use, thereby using renewable natural resources at a rate that does not exceed their regeneration capacity'  (Renewed EU Sustainable Development Strategy, 2006).

source.p: Europe's high resource consumption puts pressure on the environment both within Europe and in other regions of the world. These pressures include depletion of non-renewable resources, intensive use of renewable resources, transportation, high emissions to water, air and soil from mining activities as well as production, consumption and waste generation. It is generally accepted that there are physical limits to the continued growth of resource use. Housing, food and mobility account for the largest share of resource use and environmental pressures.

Waste disposal has the potential to cause a number of impacts on health and the environment, including emissions to air, surface water and groundwater, depending on how it is managed. Waste also represents a loss of natural resources (such as the metals or other recyclable materials it contains, or its potential as an energy source). Therefore, sound management of waste can protect public health and the quality of the environment whilst supporting conservation of natural resources.

The largest waste streams in Europe originate from construction and demolition, along with manufacturing activities. Most EU municipal waste is still sent to landfill (45 %). However, more and more municipal waste is recycled or composted (37 %), or incinerated with energy recovery (18 %).

trans-unit.source: The Water Information System for Europe (WISE) is "Your Gateway to water".
trans-unit.target: The Water Information System for Europe (WISE) is "Your Gateway to water".

source.p: It contains previously unavailable data and information collected at EU level by various institutions or bodies. Four EU partners developed WISE: The Commission (DG Environment, Eurostat & JRC) and the European Environment Agency (see more details under partners)
The WISE project started in 2002 and a concept paper was finalised a year later. The paper identifies the following core objective:

p.i: "…the European Commission (DG ENV, Eurostat and JRC) and the EEA are committed to continue the development of a new, comprehensive and shared European data and information management system for water, including river basins, following a participatory approach towards the Member States, in order to have it operational as soon as possible and to implement it, including all the various elements set out in this document, by 2010.

trans-unit.source: EU policies increasingly emphasise resource use and waste, in particular the EU Sustainable Development Strategy (SDS) and the sixth environment action programme (6EAP). The 6EAP expressly calls for 'breaking the linkages between economic growth and resource use'. In 2007, an International Panel for Sustainable Resource Management was established through cooperation between UNEP and the European Commission.
trans-unit.target: EU policies increasingly emphasise resource use and waste, in particular the EU Sustainable Development Strategy (SDS) and the sixth environment action programme (6EAP). The 6EAP expressly calls for 'breaking the linkages between economic growth and resource use'. In 2007, an International Panel for Sustainable Resource Management was established through cooperation between UNEP and the European Commission.

source.p: Almost every European Community policy affects the use and management of natural resources. Among the most important are the common agricultural policy, the common fisheries policy, the regional development policy, and the transport and energy policies. A number of cross-cutting environmental strategies address the sustainable use and management of resources, including the Sustainable Development Strategy, the 6th environment action programme, and the 2005 thematic strategies on the prevention and recycling of waste and on the sustainable use of natural resources.

The ongoing policy debate shows the need for better integration of environment- and resource-related considerations into sectoral and other policy areas. Some of the questions outstanding revolve around how to estimate the environmental impacts of resource use, what priority areas or specific resources should be the focus of policy intervention, and how to set targets and measure progress in sustainable use and management of resources.

As gains in technical efficiency are often offset by more widespread consumption, it is unlikely that resource use and waste generation can be reduced by technological improvements alone. The sustainability of current lifestyles and consumption patterns may have to be critically reviewed and technology has to be combined with other policy instruments.

Whereas EU policies on resources are still evolving, waste policies both in the EU and in individual EU Member States have been progressively put in place since the 1970s. The EU's current waste policy is based on the 'waste hierarchy'. This first aims at waste prevention, then at reducing waste disposal through re-use, recycling and other waste recovery operations. This hierarchy is likely to be strengthened by the amended Waste Framework Directive currently under revision, and by the thematic strategy on the prevention and recycling of waste.

The main waste treatment activities are regulated by the Landfill Directive, the Waste Incineration Directive and the IPPC Directive. For some special waste streams such as packaging waste, end-of-life vehicles and waste electrical and electronic equipment, the principle of the waste hierarchy has been transformed, for example by the introduction of concrete targets for recycling.

A life-cycle approach in policy-making ensures that impacts are assessed from cradle to grave, and that environmental impacts are not simply hidden by moving them to different countries or different stages of production or consumption.

Some of the questions outstanding revolve around how to estimate the environmental impacts of resource use, what priority areas or specific resources should be the focus of policy intervention, and how to set targets and measure progress in sustainable use and management of resources.

As gains in technical efficiency are often offset by more widespread consumption, it is unlikely that resource use and waste generation can be reduced by technological improvements alone. The sustainability of current lifestyles and consumption patterns may have to be critically reviewed and technology has to be combined with other policy instruments.

Whereas EU policies on resources are still evolving, waste policies both in the EU and in individual EU Member States have been progressively put in place since the 1970s. The EU's current waste policy is based on the 'waste hierarchy'. This first aims at waste prevention, then at reducing waste disposal through re-use, recycling and other waste recovery operations. This hierarchy is likely to be strengthened by the amended Waste Framework Directive currently under revision, and by the thematic strategy on the prevention and recycling of waste.

The main waste treatment activities are regulated by the Landfill Directive, the Waste Incineration Directive and the IPPC Directive. For some special waste streams such as packaging waste, end-of-life vehicles and waste electrical and electronic equipment, the principle of the waste hierarchy has been transformed, for example by the introduction of concrete targets for recycling.

A life-cycle approach in policy-making ensures that impacts are assessed from cradle to grave, and that environmental impacts are not simply hidden by moving them to different countries or different stages of production or consumption.

trans-unit.source: EEA's assessments on waste and material resources aim to support the development of policies on sustainable consumption and production, including the implementation of thematic strategies on sustainable use of natural resources and on waste prevention and recycling. Activities include monitoring and development of indicators, evaluation of the effectiveness of waste and resources policies and identification of best practices.
trans-unit.target: EEA's assessments on waste and material resources aim to support the development of policies on sustainable consumption and production, including the implementation of thematic strategies on sustainable use of natural resources and on waste prevention and recycling. Activities include monitoring and development of indicators, evaluation of the effectiveness of waste and resources policies and identification of best practices.

source.p: The work of the EEA on waste and material resources includes:

ul.li: periodic assessments and reports on waste and material flows such as the pan-European review Europe's environment — the fourth assessment;
regional overviews of implementation of sustainable consumption and production, and of waste generation and resource use in particular;
support to specific policy priorities, including sustainable use and management of natural resources and the decoupling of economic growth from resource use and waste;
support to member countries in waste reporting (including the Packaging Waste Directive) and material flow accounting;

policy effectiveness studies, e.g. packaging waste management, urban wastewater treatment systems, diversion of waste from landfills, use of economic instruments in resource management; see also Policy instruments.
work on trans-boundary shipments of waste in Europe and the environmental effects of the 'recycling society';
future outlooks and scenarios studies, such as on the development of waste generation and its environmental impacts;
indicators on municipal waste generation and generation and recycling of packaging waste;
country fact sheets on waste management in EU Member States;
an inventory of waste management companies, knowledge centres and installations in the European Environmental Technology Atlas.

source.p: The EEA's sustainable consumption and production group leads the EEA work on waste and material resources. Activities are implemented through cooperation with the EEA's European Topic Centre on Resource and Waste Management (ETC/RWM) and in collaboration with EEA's country network (Eionet). Eurostat is collecting waste data, and from 2008 it will host the environmental data centres on resources, products and waste.
